summary: A taxi driver (using a stolen hack license) is murdered and castrated. Investigation reveals the victim was Stefan Tanzic, a Serb war criminal indicted for the rape of 67 women during ethnic cleansing operations. Two of his rape victims - Marta Stevens and Anya Rugova - are arrested for his murder. Both confess. Rugova commits suicide before trial. Stevens accepts a plea deal (man two, 18 months psychiatric facility). No false accusations or wrongly accused persons in this episode - the arrested perpetrators are actually guilty and confess to the crime.

Gretchen Quinn's death is initially investigated as homicide. Detectives suspect several men including her psychiatrist Dr. Mark Daniels (who had sexual relationship with her) and TV anchor Dallas Warner (former lover). Investigation reveals her psychiatrist's prints at scene but alibi holds. Eventually the squad discovers she was a CSA survivor who wrote her own obituary and died by suicide. Her father Robert Sidarsky molested both Gretchen and her sister Ellen. While Dr. Daniels exploited a vulnerable patient, and Dallas Warner was involved with her, the episode concludes Gretchen took her own life. No one was falsely accused of crimes they didn't commit - the psychiatrist did sleep with his patient (unethical but consensual per transcript), Warner did have an affair, and the father did commit CSA (though outside statute of limitations). This is a case about harm FROM accurate accusations, not false ones.

Transcript is completely corrupted with encoding errors, rendering all dialogue unreadable. Cannot reliably identify suspects, victims, accusations, or outcomes. Episode requires re-transcription from clean source before tagging is possible.

Episode involves two separate cases: (1) Officer Peter Francis Ridley, a Vice cop who is a serial killer of 18 prostitutes over 31 years; (2) Dennis Caulfield, who murdered Tracy Henderson, his secret girlfriend. Tracy Henderson's boyfriend Dennis is initially treated as alibied, but later proven guilty. Travis Hall, a parolee volunteer, is found dead (OD'd before Tracy's murder), clearing him. The key false accusation involves the implicit suspicion of Travis Hall before his body is discovered, though this is minimal. Officer Ridley confesses to 18 murders but explicitly denies killing Tracy Henderson, which proves accurate—he is innocent of that specific murder.

ADA Karen Fitzgerald is raped and murdered in Central Park. SVU investigates multiple suspects including Kenneth Maggio (convicted sex offender), Jean Dussault (Labor Day rapist), and Richard White (date rapist Fitzgerald prosecuted). White is ultimately revealed as the killer. During investigation, Maggio is briefly suspected but cleared when his physical injuries from prison assault prove he cannot commit rape. Dussault is ruled out when found dead in Canada. Both suspects were investigated privately without public exposure.

Seth Langdon is murdered on a rooftop after a party. Jesse Hansen is ultimately revealed as the killer, manipulated by his brother Ray Gunther (the 'Parkway Rapist'). Ray Gunther is initially suspected due to DNA bloodline match but is cleared when full testing shows it was Jesse. Steven Hale, William Langdon's employee, is also wrongly suspected early in the investigation due to jealousy concerns and his presence at the party, but is cleared when his alibi is confirmed.

No falsely accused innocent persons identified. Episode focuses on exposing Judge Varella's corruption and Gina Silver's justified homicide. One suspect (Delfino Melendez) was briefly investigated but cleared through alibi verification without public exposure or significant harm. The episode centers on systemic corruption rather than wrongful accusations.

Andrew Harlin found dead, strangled in bondage harness. Squad questions numerous lovers (male and female), sex workers, and associates. Several people wrongly suspected and publicly questioned including Charlie Poe (boat charter operator who had sexual relationship with Harlin), Bull Dozer (porn aspiring actor), Becky Sorenson (painter/ex-girlfriend), Natasha (spa worker), Sonya Pietrovicz (singer/sex worker), and Katya Ivanova (sex worker). Alexander Strizhov ultimately confesses to murdering Harlin (and later Sonya and her aunt) out of obsessive love for Katya. Multiple suspects experienced public exposure at workplaces and through police questioning in front of colleagues/clients.

Dean Woodruff is shot in a parked car. Stephanie Mulroney, from a powerful political family, witnesses the shooting. After investigation reveals she knew the victim from college and lied about their prior relationship, detectives arrest her for murder two, believing she lured him to his death for revenge over a past sexual encounter. She is remanded without bail. A second identical shooting of Stanley Brecker leads police to Arthur Prewitt, who confesses to both murders. Stephanie is exonerated and released. Captain Cragen apologizes publicly. Detective Munch suspects the Mulroneys orchestrated the outcome but cannot prove it.

SVU reopens three 1995 rape cases after DNA matches them to 'John Doe 121.' The statute of limitations is about to expire. No false suspects are identified—the episode focuses on legal/procedural battles to obtain a John Doe DNA warrant and one victim's refusal to name the perpetrator she believes has reformed. No innocent persons are publicly accused or harmed by mistaken accusations.

Dean Woodruff shot in parked car with woman Stephanie Mulroney present. SVU charges Mulroney with murder two based on prior relationship at Barrett College and motive theory. She is arraigned, remanded without bail, publicly accused. Later, second shooting of Stanley Brecker reveals serial killer Arthur Pruitt. Pruitt confesses to Woodruff murder. Case against Mulroney dismissed. Judge apologizes to Mulroney family. Mulroney clearly innocent, suffered public arrest, arraignment, media circus, jail remand.

An elderly woman (Lenora Bernstein, 72) is robbed, raped, and dies of a heart attack. Two teens (Carlos Medina and Alfonso Cardenas) are arrested for robbery. DNA reveals neither committed the rape. A third person, initially believed to be delivery man Stan Bosic, is investigated. Stan is publicly considered a hero for calling 911 and attempting CPR. Investigation reveals Stan lied—his partner Jimmy Walp actually found the victim. Jimmy is ultimately arrested for the rape/murder. Carlos and Alfonso, though arrested and jailed, are later cleared of the rape charge (proven innocent of sexual assault, partially involved in robbery). Stan Bosic is briefly suspected but cleared when witness lineup identifies Jimmy. Emmanuel Clemente is briefly questioned but has an alibi. The episode centers on identifying the actual rapist among multiple false leads.

Sylvia Hadley, wife of a Christian college administrator and daughter-in-law of the college president, is found strangled in her hotel room. Initially treated as robbery/rape, the investigation reveals complex family dynamics. Brad Weber, the college's financial manager, is accused after admitting to kissing Sylvia but denying further involvement. DNA clears him. The case ultimately points to Ben Hadley Jr. (the victim's husband), who lied about being in Baltimore. The transcript reveals Dr. Ben Hadley Sr. had a two-year affair with Sylvia (his daughter-in-law) and she was pregnant. The son appears to have killed her, likely after discovering the affair/pregnancy.

16-year-old Karen Raye files false rape report against fictional 'Yachtsman' to cover consensual sex with 21-year-old boyfriend Keith. Investigation leads to Keith Van Essian, whose computer system was used by actual predator Harry Waters to store illegal files. Keith is publicly accused and interrogated before truth emerges. Waters is real predator with multiple victims.

SVU investigates a serial subway rapist. They arrest Bruce Abbott, a window display designer, after he rubs against a woman on the subway. Witnesses identify him, but all seven previous rape victims fail to ID him in a lineup. He is released. The actual rapist, Sal Avelino, is later caught and confesses. Bruce was publicly accused and wrestled down on the subway, but was innocent of the rapes.

Episode focuses on the rape of journalist Sarah Logan by two men (Krieger and McConagh), both eventually identified and proven guilty. Sarah is murdered by an obsessed third party before trial. No false suspects are identified in the transcript - all accused parties (Krieger, McConagh, Lexner) are guilty of their respective crimes. Krieger's date turns him in; McConagh confesses. The bombing was perpetrated by William Lexner, an obsessed individual unconnected to the original rape.

Episode follows investigation and prosecution of piano teacher Larry Holt for child sexual abuse and child pornography. All investigated individuals (Holt, Evan, Jonathan) are ultimately shown to be actual perpetrators, not falsely accused. No innocent persons are publicly exposed or harmed by false accusations in this episode.

Episode centers on rescuing Ilena Condrescu, a Romanian woman held captive and tortured for three years by Randolph Morrow and his wife Louise. Ilena's aunt Constanta is murdered by Louise Morrow when she tries to help. No false accusations of sex crimes are present. The investigation correctly identifies the perpetrators. Morrow is arrested and Ilena is rescued from a hidden compartment under his bed.

Episode centers on Michael Goren, a 16-year-old ward who confesses to killing his guardian Andrew Croft. Investigation reveals Croft was a convicted child molester whose criminal record was erased by defense contractor Radial Velocity for national security purposes. Michael ultimately discloses years of sexual abuse by Croft and supervisor Craig Prince, who is arrested. No false suspects were publicly accused or harmed; the investigation correctly identified perpetrators (Croft, Prince) and victim (Michael). The Morris Commission subplot involves internal police evaluation, not criminal accusation.

Nafeesa Amir is raped by her boyfriend Daoud Tarzi and later murdered by her brother Jaleel in an honor killing. Tarzi is initially arrested for rape and attempted murder based on DNA evidence and his 'confession' ('I am responsible for this'), but he passes a polygraph and claims he meant he felt responsible, not that he attacked her. Evidence later proves Jaleel committed the murder. Tarzi's identity and whereabouts were previously sought by a private investigator hired by Nafeesa's father, leading to a violent confrontation. The episode shows Tarzi being publicly accused and arrested despite being innocent of the murder and stabbing, though guilty of statutory rape given the cultural context.

This episode follows the investigation and prosecution of Kenneth Cleary, a serial rapist who attacks women in both New York and Philadelphia. Cleary is the actual perpetrator—not a false suspect. The episode ends with Cleary being shot and killed by his wife Meredith after he attacks her, with Harper Anderson (a previous victim) present. No innocent persons are falsely accused or publicly exposed in this episode. The focus is on building a case against the guilty party and the emotional toll on victims and the perpetrator's wife.

Seven-year-old Emily McKenna is hospitalized with severe head trauma and evidence of long-term sexual abuse. Detectives initially suspect her biological father Denny Corea, then stepfather Randall McKenna, then stepbrother Justin McKenna. All three are publicly accused and exposed. Eventually, detectives discover Emily's mother Jamie McKenna is the true abuser. Denny assaults Randall based on the false belief that Randall molested Emily. Justin is arrested and held. All three innocent parties suffer significant public and legal consequences before Jamie confesses.

Seven-year-old Elias Barrera shoots and kills a classmate at school. Initially charged with murder, investigation reveals he witnessed a drug-related murder committed by 'Machete' (identified as Nicky Crow) the night before, took the gun in fear, and was trying to defend himself from gang members at the school fence when he accidentally shot Carly Jackson. Elias is publicly accused, arrested, perp-walked, remanded to detention, and subjected to intense media scrutiny and death threats before charges are withdrawn when the ADA accepts he lacked capacity. The episode ends with Elias being violently attacked by a 12-year-old vigilante.

Two victims found at a convenience store: night manager Maggie Sandomir (raped and shot) and customer Earl Miller (stabbed). Detectives initially suspect Mark Nash, a schizophrenic patient who refused medication and was close to Maggie. Nash is arrested, publicly accused, and coerced into taking anti-psychotic medication to testify. The actual perpetrator is revealed to be Earl Miller (alias for ex-con Earl Gilmore), who raped and killed Maggie. Nash acted in defense of Maggie by stabbing Gilmore. After being medicated and forced into lucidity, Nash commits suicide in the hospital. Ben Moreland, another mentally ill patient who stalked Maggie, is also briefly suspected and falsely confesses but is cleared by DNA.

Patricia Andrews accuses her husband, Sgt. Lloyd Andrews (a Homicide detective), of rape. The case goes to trial. The judge ultimately finds Lloyd not guilty on all counts. Throughout the episode, Patricia exhibits physical violence toward Lloyd (throwing objects, attacking with a knife), and there are four prior domestic dispute calls to their residence. Patricia later attempts to recant, then testifies under pressure from the ADA who threatened her with assault charges. Lloyd admits to cheating and apologizing just to keep the peace, not because he raped her. No one is proven or strongly implied innocent of a sexual offense they were accused of—Lloyd is acquitted at trial, but the show does not clearly establish his innocence; it presents a 'he said, she said' marital dispute with mutual violence. There is no qualifying false suspect with public exposure harm per the rubric.

A family of con artists stages a fake rape at a high-profile hotel opening to extort money from the hotel chain. They select Russell Ramsay, a registered sex offender with a prior statutory rape conviction, as their target. Siobhan Miller (age 23, posing as 17) seduces Ramsay to her hotel room, then her sister-in-law beats her to simulate a violent rape. Ramsay is arrested based on victim ID, DNA evidence, and his prior conviction. The detectives eventually uncover the elaborate fraud scheme involving Siobhan, her brother Beau, sister-in-law Patricia Ann, and cousin Kyle Kivlahan (posing as hotel desk clerk Terry Wilde). By the time Ramsay is cleared, he has been murdered at Rikers Island after being beaten and raped by other inmates. The episode ends with Detective Munch informing Ramsay's ex-girlfriend Shelly Leevak (his statutory rape victim who still loved him) of his exoneration and death.

A 16-year-old gymnast (later revealed to be 19) is murdered. Kyle Hubert, a wealthy donor who had a consensual relationship with the victim, is initially suspected and publicly confronted. He is cleared when the real killer, Lori (a jealous teammate), confesses. Hubert suffers workplace/public exposure despite innocence of murder.

College student Kelly D'leah is found in bushes after being drugged with GHB and raped. Investigation initially focuses on frat brothers Joe Templeton and Hank Ludlow, but DNA reveals the rapist was Wallace 'Wally' Parker. Multiple people wrongly suspected: campus vagrant Harry arrested and threatened with rape charge; Joe and Hank arrested for rape/conspiracy before DNA cleared them (though Joe/Hank remain culpable for GHB possession/conspiracy). The sorority sisters Tess and Jodie drugged Kelly in revenge scheme. Harry subjected to interrogation threats and forced blood draw despite being innocent homeless man. Joe and Hank publicly arrested at fraternity in front of peers before DNA exclusion.

Kelly D'leah is found semi-conscious in bushes after being drugged with GHB and raped. Investigation initially focuses on Joe Templeton and Hank Ludlow (fraternity brothers she was partying with), but DNA from semen matches Wally Parker instead. Evidence shows sorority sisters Tess Michner and Jodie Tomlinson manufactured the GHB as revenge against Kelly. Joe Templeton and Hank Ludlow are arrested but DNA clears them as the rapist, though Joe is implicated in conspiracy. Harry (a homeless man) is briefly suspected but cleared via blood test. The episode ends mid-transcript with Wally about to testify, claiming possible consent based on prior friendly interactions.

High school teacher Marnie Owens is raped and murdered. Her student Ethan Chance becomes initial suspect after being last to see her alive and fleeing when found. Investigation reveals Marnie had sex addiction and engaged in online hookups and sex club activities. Ethan is publicly arrested at memorial service but is innocent. Dr. Byron Marks initially lies about affair with Marnie but is cleared. Phillip Montrose, a stalker from sex club, is eventually indicted for manslaughter after grand jury testimony revealing Marnie's sexual history.

Two paroled sex offenders (Thomas Marchek and Craig Moss) are murdered execution-style. Investigation initially focuses on victims' families and then Sam Winfield of Citizen Watch, who distributed flyers about parolees and threatened them. Winfield is arrested for attempted murder of a third parolee (Campbell) but did not commit the murders. Louise Durning, an HIV-positive social worker at a clinic, confesses to the murders—she killed the men because they had HIV and she feared they would infect others as she had been infected by her rapist. Gloria Palmera (Marchek's ex-girlfriend) initially confessed falsely to protect Louise. Multiple innocents were publicly accused during investigation: Lindsay Branson (Marchek victim's mother), Josh Branson (victim's father), James Campbell (parolee falsely suspected then targeted), and Sam Winfield (Citizen Watch leader).

Sergeant Karen Smythe is raped during a warehouse break-in response. Initially investigated as a serial rape case. Later revealed to be an attack orchestrated by three corrupt fellow officers (Bates, Towne, Murray) who were running drugs and feared she would expose them. She was a confidential IAB field associate. Internal Affairs pressured her to recant the rape to protect their drug case. A homeless man was briefly suspected after being found with Smythe's stolen ID, but was quickly ruled out via alibi. No qualifying false suspects with public exposure harm.

SVU investigates a serial child abductor/rapist. Three suspects are publicly accused before the actual perpetrator (Clayton Mills) is caught: Oliver Tunney (a registered sex offender questioned at his workplace and brought in for parole violation), Joe Hayes (ex-con confronted at his job), and Phil Dartman (janitor questioned in prior case). All three are later cleared. Tunney is publicly arrested at his workplace. Hayes is publicly confronted by detectives at his job site. Both suffered workplace exposure as a consequence of being accused.

Narcotics Sgt. Frank Foster takes hostages trying to find his runaway daughter Jill. The SVU investigates connections to rave promoter/pimp Lance Kanick. Civilian volunteer Tito Frank is murdered by Kanick. Detective Fin Tutuola uses excessive force on Kanick to extract Jill's location, but she dies of an overdose before they reach her. Captain Cragen faces disciplinary review for handling of the investigation. No qualifying false accusation cases - the main suspect Kanick is guilty, and while Foster took hostages (a crime), he was not accused of a sex crime and the episode focuses on his daughter's case, not wrongful accusation against him.

A married couple with a shared psychotic sexual disorder stages fake rape scenarios with male escorts. The wife pretends to be assaulted, then the husband 'rescues' her by attacking the escort. Three escorts are attacked (one dies, one comatose, one injured). The couple books escorts using stolen credit card numbers. No innocent suspects are publicly accused or exposed in this episode - the investigation correctly focuses on finding the perpetrators who are attacking the escorts.

A body is found buried in a yard. Detectives initially suspect the previous homeowners, Dr. Brad Stanton and his second wife Pam, of killing Brad's ex-wife Abbey. The investigation clears them when Abbey is found alive in hospice. The body is identified as Ava Parulis, but is actually her twin sister Irina. Ava had been impersonating Irina for three years after Romanian diplomat Razvan Toscu murdered Irina (mistaking her for Ava). The real killer is ultimately identified as Toscu, who used diplomatic immunity to evade justice. Multiple innocent people were publicly accused and harmed during the investigation.

Episode involves misidentification of remains. Initially believed to be Abbey Stanton (first wife of surgeon Brad Stanton), bones are later identified as Irina Burton. Investigation focuses on Brad Stanton and wife Pam as potential suspects before discovering the victim is actually Irina Burton, killed by diplomat Razvan Toscu who mistook her for her twin sister Ava. Brad and Pam Stanton are cleared. Multiple men in Ava's life (Matt Sloane, Paul Amis, unnamed abusive husband) are investigated and cleared.

Episode involves the investigation of Veronica Tandy's rape and murder. Greg Spector is accused and questioned as an early suspect but is later cleared. He was a former security supervisor fired by the victim and threatened her, but the investigation pivots to Jason Mayberry, who confesses to the crime. Spector experienced public exposure when detectives questioned him at his workplace about the murder.

Daniel Varney, suffering from advanced tertiary syphilis that destroyed his brain, murdered four people. Norman Fredericks was arrested for the first murder based on DNA evidence from a prostitute he solicited, but was later cleared when a second murder occurred while he had an alibi. An insurance company (All-Atlantic Life) knew Varney had syphilis seven years earlier but failed to notify him or health authorities as required by law; one penicillin shot then could have prevented the brain damage and murders. The episode focuses primarily on the manhunt and Varney's illness rather than wrongful accusation consequences, but Fredericks experienced arrest and interrogation for a murder he didn't commit.

Megan Ramsey accuses her father Evan of childhood sexual abuse and current abuse of her younger sister Lily. Investigation reveals Megan's memories were implanted by her therapist using sodium amytal. Medical exam shows Megan is a virgin, proving no rape occurred. Megan plants evidence (pornography and underwear) to frame her father. Evan is arrested, publicly humiliated, then released when evidence is exposed as fabricated. He is later murdered. Jody (Megan's sister) eventually confesses to accidentally shooting him during a confrontation.

Eric Plummer was wrongfully convicted of rape and attempted murder based on weak evidence and eyewitness ID presented by Det. Benson. He served 7 years in prison where he was beaten, raped, and tortured. After DNA exoneration and release, he changed his name to Norman Webber. He later murdered four people connected to Benson's cases as revenge, saying he was 'freeing them from misery.' The episode centers on his stalking of Benson and the investigation that ultimately identifies him.

A baby (Emma Daricek) is kidnapped from a supermarket by crack addict Alicia Brown, who gives the baby to illegal adoption broker Mark Sanford. Investigation leads to discovery of Sanford's black-market adoption network and the 12-year-old cold case of Jennifer Talmadge's murder and her baby's kidnapping. Robert Cook is initially investigated as potential father/killer but is cleared. Linda Cook (his ex-wife) is ultimately revealed as Jennifer's killer who forged adoption papers. The episode focuses heavily on the custody battle over Tyler Blake (Stephen Talmadge), but no one in the custody dispute is falsely accused of a sex crime—they're fighting over legal custody rights. Michele Daricek (mother of kidnapped baby Emma) is briefly considered as possibly having harmed her own child due to postpartum depression, but this suspicion is contained to police investigation and she is quickly cleared when Emma is found with the illegal adoption network.

Leon Tate, an HIV-positive parolee with history of underage sex crimes, is aggressively surveilled and publicly confronted by Detective Stabler. He is accused of rapes/murders he did not commit. He is arrested, questioned for attempted rape of 14-year-old Nashika Morris (interrupted before intercourse), and becomes prime suspect in serial murders. He dies of drug overdose before being cleared. Evidence later proves Malik Harris committed all the murders. Leon's mother explicitly accuses police of murdering her innocent son.

Dr. Max Kleberg is murdered and his wife Peyton is raped. Investigation pursues multiple innocent suspects: Martin Welker (disgruntled patient from impotency trial, publicly accused despite prior innocence), Jesse Kleberg (son accused of patricide due to gambling debts and resentment, arrested and questioned), and Peyton Kleberg herself (investigated as potential mastermind after affair discovery). True perpetrator is Vincent Boyd, Lara Todd's abusive ex-boyfriend. Multiple people suffer public exposure, workplace questioning, and reputational harm before being cleared.

Roger Berry was wrongfully convicted 18 years prior by Detective Hawkins through a coerced confession. When similar murders occur, Roger becomes the prime suspect again but is eventually cleared. The real killer, Arthur Blessard, is identified and arrested. Roger's wrongful conviction was obtained through deceptive interrogation tactics where Hawkins fed him case details and falsely promised he could 'go home' if he signed a confession. The innocent Roger Berry spent 18 years in prison.

Wesley Jansen, a man doing gay-for-pay porn to finance his daughter's CF treatment, is shot and raped. The investigation reveals he was caught between his wife's porn director Cal Oman (who was obsessed with his wife Jaina) and his desperate attempts to support his sick daughter. Wesley ultimately confesses to killing Oman in self-defense/struggle. No innocent person is publicly accused or harmed by false accusation in this episode - the victim becomes the perpetrator, and the investigation follows the actual guilty party throughout.

Two Asian women are attacked in Chinatown. Initial investigation focuses on gang members Johnny Chen and Dao Tran, both later cleared. Through DNA evidence linking the perpetrator to convicted rapist Harold Starnes, detectives ultimately identify Darrell Guan (Starnes' son via rape) as the actual perpetrator. Johnny Chen is publicly accused and arrested for raping his sister Helen; Dao Tran is accused of the same crime. Both are exposed to colleagues/community and face arrest/interrogation despite being innocent.

Cassie Adams, a 5-year-old foster child, is found beaten to death at a construction site. Detectives initially suspect Danny Marston (construction worker who befriended Cassie) and then Glenn (Cassie's 14-year-old foster brother with developmental delays). Both are publicly questioned and exposed before being cleared. The actual perpetrators are Dorothy Rudd (foster grandmother) and Jane Rudd (foster mother), who subjected Cassie to prolonged torture and beating. Glenn witnessed the abuse and tried to save Cassie by moving her body to the construction site in a delusional state inspired by his video game.

Male stripper Peter Smith reports being raped by three women at a bachelorette party. Initially treated with skepticism by police and prosecutors, his claim gains credibility when one of the accused women (Sydney Green) is found dead in what appears to be autoerotic asphyxiation but is later revealed to be murder. The other two women (Pam Adler and Amelia Chase) are prosecuted for both rape and murder after evidence suggests they killed Sydney to prevent her from cooperating with Peter's civil suit. Andrew Green, Sydney's estranged husband, is initially suspected of murdering her for insurance money but is cleared when the murder is linked to the rape case.

Nicole Manning is brutally attacked in a parking garage and subjected to a crude C-section; her baby is killed. Initially, Kyle Novacek (a heroin user with a prior assault record who test-drove Nicole's car and was her secret lover) is investigated. Erin Sena (a fired nurse with a grudge against Nicole) is also suspected. Both are later cleared when evidence points to Nicole's husband, psychiatrist Richard Manning, who attacked his wife to eliminate the baby she was carrying with another man.

Maria Ramos and her sons witness drug lord Fredo Garcia commit murder. When Miguel is shot in a drive-by and later smothered in the hospital, detectives discover Fredo terrorized the family for years, forcing them into his drug operation. Maria ultimately shoots Fredo in what she claims is self-defense. While there are tragic consequences throughout, there are no qualifying false accusations that meet the rubric criteria - no innocent persons are publicly accused and then cleared. Fredo is the actual perpetrator. Maria's initial reluctance to cooperate stems from fear, not false accusation. The detectives' investigative process does not produce false suspects who are later cleared with public exposure.

Double murder investigation of Edward Boggs and MFPCA Agent Pam Tilden. Multiple suspects pursued: Scotty (deaf burglar), Harry Baker (teenage animal abuser), and Joe Poletti (serial rapist working at animal kennel). Scotty cleared early via evidence. Harry arrested and interrogated but released when evidence points elsewhere. Poletti becomes primary suspect but no murder charges stick; convicted only of obscenity for violent writings. Investigation ongoing at episode end.

Paula Grace is found raped and murdered under the West Side Highway with counterfeit cancer drugs in her trunk. A second rape victim, Francesca Jesner, claims a cop pulled her over and raped her. Investigation targets Officer Al Marcosi, who was unaccounted for during both attacks and had suspicious behaviors (car wash, tire replacement). Detectives suspect him of rape-murder and prior misconduct with a missing prostitute. IAB investigates him publicly. Eventually evidence points away from Marcosi toward a cop impersonator. Marcosi is subjected to interrogation, public exposure at his command, and desk duty pending IAB investigation. He is strongly implied innocent of the rapes/murder but guilty of other misconduct (sex with prostitutes on duty, rule violations).

This episode does not feature anyone falsely accused. Matthew Brodus is a convicted serial killer correctly identified as guilty of 12+ murders including Debbie Cooper's. The detectives work to prove his connection to the Cooper case before his execution. No innocent person is accused or publicly exposed in this episode. Robert Rule (inmate) is correctly imprisoned for rape/manslaughter. The episode focuses on investigative procedure and interrogation tactics, not wrongful accusations.

Cynthia Wilmont, 14, is raped at a party by Nick Radsen (also 14). She initially refuses to report, then falsely accuses substitute teacher Ross McKenzie. Detectives obtain medical records without consent, question her at school, triggering an assault on her (pushed down stairs). McKenzie is publicly confronted at his school, arrested, and subjected to DNA testing before being cleared. The false accusation causes professional consequences for McKenzie including termination proceedings. Nick Radsen is the actual perpetrator who committed statutory rape.

After cellist Cassie Germaine is assaulted in her apartment, detectives discover hidden cameras throughout her home. Investigation initially focuses on her conductor Robert Prescott, who owns the apartment and has a history of secretly videotaping women he's involved with. Prescott is publicly confronted and questioned but is proven innocent when his alibi checks out. The actual perpetrator is Terry Willard, an obsessed stalker who planted the cameras and maintained a delusional online journal about a relationship with Cassie that never existed. Prescott experiences public exposure when detectives confront him about the cameras and his relationships with multiple women.

No false accusations or innocent suspects identified. Roy Barnett is the perpetrator throughout. Sam Cavanaugh is the victim who initially cooperates, warns Barnett during sting, later agrees to testify, then attempts suicide. Tommy Priore and Benjamin Tucker are identified as past victims. The episode centers on prosecutorial challenges and ADA Cabot's illegal search to obtain evidence (videotapes). No person meets criteria for inclusion: Barnett is guilty, and all other persons are victims, not falsely accused.

Patricia Stephens, 16-year-old stepdaughter of Judge Thornburg, is raped and murdered. Initial suspect Thomas 'Bird' Gordon, a parolee convicted by Judge Thornburg, is arrested for rape-murder and attempted murder of the judge. Gordon claims Patricia solicited him to kill her stepfather. Investigation reveals Patricia became pregnant at age 11 by Judge Thornburg and gave birth to Brian, whom the Thornburgs adopted. Patricia's mother Brook ultimately confesses to killing her daughter after learning the truth about the pregnancy. Gordon was publicly arrested and charged with crimes he did not commit (the murder and attempted murder of the judge), though he did rape Patricia.

A locksmith, Danny Ryan, is falsely accused of rape and attempted murder after evidence (jewelry, pantyhose) is planted in his work van and his fingerprints are found at crime scenes where he legitimately installed locks. The actual perpetrators are con artists Edward Crandall (using alias 'Edwin Todd') and Denise Cormier (using alias 'Denise Carlson') who staged rapes to cover a murder-for-money scheme. Ryan is arrested, held on $500k bail, and faces serious charges before being cleared when his DNA doesn't match. The exposure appears limited to law enforcement and legal proceedings.

A rape victim is found with a child's finger in her purse, leading detectives to investigate a decades-old child murder. The victim, Claire Rinato, is initially accused of killing her baby sister Lisa 14 years prior based on her mother Grace's claims and Claire's documented history of violent rages. However, investigation reveals Grace killed both Lisa and an earlier infant son Anthony. Claire is charged with murder to pressure a confession, then charges are dropped when Grace's guilt is established. Arthur Felton is arrested for the rape based on eyewitness ID (Malcolm, a law student).

Katie Tolliver, a 22-year-old woman with Down syndrome, becomes pregnant after being raped by her grocery store employer. The investigation initially focuses on several innocent men before identifying the true perpetrator, Abe Cheney, who had been systematically exploiting multiple intellectually disabled employees.

Jamie Doyle (16-year-old transgender sex worker) is accidentally killed by Bobby Douglas during an arson attack on St. Martha's Church. Bobby was acting out rage from sexual abuse he suffered at age 14 by Bishop Mallinson (not Father Michael Sweeney). Father Michael is initially suspected and arrested for abuse based on Bobby's accusations, but he was innocent - he was protecting the real abuser (Bishop Mallinson) through confessional seal. Other boys (Todd Ramsay, Ben Campion, unnamed victims) were genuinely abused and received settlements. Darius Retafian's mother attempted to recycle old abuse claims against Father Michael for financial gain, but Darius was actually abused by a different priest at his school. No qualifying false accusation victims - Father Michael was publicly accused and arrested, but the harm was limited to legal process without additional public exposure consequences detailed, and the case was dropped when truth emerged.

SVU investigates a series of murders connected to a prostitute named Maggie Peterson (real name Margaret Peterson). She claims self-defense in multiple killings of violent johns, but investigation reveals she is a serial killer who targeted violent men to justify her actions. The episode focuses on her prosecution for capital murder. No innocent persons are falsely accused or publicly exposed - all investigated suspects (Shawn Becker, Leonard Graves, etc.) are confirmed victims of Maggie's murders. The case involves her manipulation and sociopathic behavior rather than wrongful accusation of innocents.

A kindergartner's drawing leads SVU to investigate Gloria Stanfield for sexually abusing her stepson Kyle (17). During the investigation, Gloria's husband Lawrence Fuller is murdered. Kyle is arrested for the murder based on his bat being the weapon and his prints on it. Later, Gloria marries Kyle and claims she was raped by her lover Frank Barbarossa, framing him for both rape and murder. Eventually it's revealed Gloria orchestrated the murder through Barbarossa and framed both men. Kyle was falsely accused and arrested for murder; Barbarossa was falsely accused of rape and murder (though guilty of murder).

Alzheimer's patient Bess Sherman is tortured with cigarette burns. Investigation initially focuses on her son Joe Sherman (suspected of abuse/neglect) and grandson Andy Sherman (suspected of elder abuse/check fraud). Both are publicly questioned/accused but cleared. The actual perpetrator of the burns was Hal Shipley (nurse's aide), with Hope Garrett (administrator) later revealed as attempted murderer via epinephrine injection.

Two women murdered in Central Park. Initial investigation focuses on Roger Pomerantz (due to threatening calls to victim Dr. Greta Esterman) and Mario Molinari (HIV-positive man who may have motive). Both are cleared. The actual killer is revealed to be Arthur Esterman, the victim's husband, who orchestrated both murders to inherit his wife's money while maintaining his secret life with escorts. Roger Pomerantz was publicly confronted and attacked by the widower Arthur Esterman at the precinct.

Three women connected to Russian mob boss Sergei Perlman are raped by a serial rapist. DNA leads SVU to Peter Sipes, a protected witness in WITSEC (formerly Gregory Rossovitch), who testified against the Russian mob. Peter is publicly investigated and his cover is blown when a former criminal associate (Michael Kerring) recognizes him at the precinct. Peter is later proven innocent via DNA; his son Gavin is the actual rapist. Peter and a US Marshal are murdered during Gavin's arrest. Peter's entire life in witness protection is destroyed by the investigation, culminating in his death.

SVU investigates a pedophile ring involving smuggled children from Guatemala. A boy named José dies after being locked in a bus luggage compartment while escaping his abuser Bret Jansen. The investigation uncovers multiple pedophiles including Dr. Stewart Lynch, travel agent Anthony Damon, and dentist Walter Massey. All suspects are guilty of the crimes they're accused of—no false accusations are present. Massey ultimately confesses to murdering Jansen.

Terry Jessup kidnaps and murders Susie Marshall, then kidnaps Nina Tremain. Episode follows investigation leading directly to the actual perpetrator. No innocent persons are publicly accused or harmed by false accusations. Terry Jessup is the actual guilty party throughout. Mothers Violet Tremain and Ronnie Marshall are victims/witnesses, not accused parties. No red herrings or wrongfully accused individuals appear in the episode.

Comatose patient Stephanie Rawley is found pregnant. Multiple suspects are investigated including her fiancé David Andersen, physical therapist Clark Jensen, custodian Hill, vending machine attendant Wesley Dilbert (necrophiliac), and Dr. Mandell. Wesley is publicly confronted and arrested for necrophilia (videotaped with corpse). David is threatened with jail. Ultimately Dr. Mandell is revealed to have artificially inseminated Stephanie for stem cell research funded by billionaire Davis Langley. Several innocent people were accused and exposed during the investigation.

Episode involves two juveniles who committed a rape-murder. While there are suspects investigated early (cannabis club members, an angry husband), none are accused publicly or significantly harmed by false accusation before being cleared. The husband (Paglione) had a solid alibi and was briefly questioned but not publicly exposed. Cannabis club members were interviewed but not accused of the murder. No qualifying false suspect cases meet the harm threshold.

Karl Sirett was Jackie's ex-boyfriend and initially accused/arrested for raping her based on her identification and him following her at the subway. He was later cleared when Jackie revealed she had dated him consensually and falsely accused him because detectives showed her his photo. The actual perpetrator was her father Tom Landricks, who attempted to impregnate her using other men's semen via syringe. While Karl was arrested and his case went to a judge (who ruled police misconduct), there is no evidence of public exposure beyond police questioning. The harm was primarily legal/reputational within the criminal justice system.

Rebecca Kurtz, 6, is shot during a video store robbery and dies. Investigation reveals she was sexually abused (gonorrhea). Initially, police suspect her adoptive father Peter Kurtz based on a prior allegation from older sister Missy, then suspect Missy's boyfriend Joey Field. Peter Kurtz is publicly accused at the hospital and refuses STD testing. Joey Field is arrested for rape and triple murder. Eventually revealed that Missy (who had previously filed false abuse complaint against Peter) orchestrated everything: she abused Rebecca, paid Eric Campbell to shoot her, manipulated Joey into helping, then falsely accused Joey of rape to cover her crimes. Peter Kurtz was innocent of both the old and new allegations.

Episode centers on cocaine smuggled in baby formula cans that kills infant Jawan Hauser. Investigation leads to Derek Pfeiffer, a stockbroker who was murdered. Wife Laura Pfeiffer initially presented as uninvolved but revealed as active participant. Corrupt cop Brad Kendall involved, killed by Detective Stabler in self-defense. Keith Gerard revealed as mastermind running mothers-with-babies smuggling ring. No qualifying false suspects: Derek Pfeiffer murdered before innocence/guilt established; Laura Pfeiffer confirmed as participant; all others were actual perpetrators or not publicly accused.

Carlos Torres, a drug dealer, dies from internal bleeding after being sodomized with a plunger by Officer Luke Edmunds (with assistance from Officer Les Cooper) in a precinct bathroom. Torres was arrested at Club Rendezvous and brought to the 29th precinct before being transferred to the Tombs. Investigation reveals Edmunds and Cooper killed multiple drug dealers—Edmunds for revenge (his brother died from drugs), Cooper for money. Willie Angel, a dealer, was shot by Cooper, framed with a drop gun, and wrongfully convicted of attempted murder. Angel is paralyzed and imprisoned. When his innocence is corroborated by Edmunds' confession, he's released. This episode demonstrates wrongful conviction through police fabrication of evidence and perjured testimony.

Detectives investigate the death of a one-month-old infant found in the Hudson River. The baby was killed via tricyclic antidepressants. Investigation reveals the mother, Andrea Brown, euthanized her daughter Sarah who had been diagnosed with Tay-Sachs disease. Dr. Judah Platner, the family pediatrician, provided the prescription. The case involves medical ethics around euthanasia of terminally ill children. No false accusations are made - the investigation correctly identifies Andrea Brown and Dr. Platner as responsible parties, and both admit their involvement. Several people are questioned during the investigation (Angela Savvas, Ellen Swanson, Patty Swanson, Paul Howley) but these are routine investigative interviews that do not result in public accusations or harm.

Meredith McGrath, a cyber-vigilante working with U.S. Attorney to catch online pedophiles, is raped and murdered along with her husband Roger. Investigation reveals she was killed by Nicholas Taylor (Nick2Shy) who was producing child pornography of his own daughter Amy. During investigation, detectives publicly confront Ron Crowley at his workplace (copy shop) believing he kidnapped Mia Van Wagner, but he only helped her travel to meet Erich Tassig in Prague. Crowley is innocent of murder and kidnapping - the girl went willingly (though he committed passport fraud). Tassig is also cleared of the McGrath murders. Both men face public exposure and consequences unrelated to the actual murders.

A Tibetan torture survivor is murdered. SVU initially suspects her husband Preston Bennett (who entered a marriage of convenience to help her immigrate), then his business partner Ryan Chambers (who actually married her). Both were innocent. The husband was publicly accused/investigated and had to explain his relationship lies. The actual killer was Jerry Dupree, a shoe fetishist who murdered Kunsong when she accidentally came to his apartment. The husband and business partner both faced exposure of immigration fraud but were cleared of the murder.

Carmen Trancoso, a film student, is found dead after falling from the Lamerly family penthouse. Initially believed to be suicide, investigation reveals she was murdered by her ex-boyfriend Drew Lamerly. During the investigation, detectives initially suspect Tom Paysen (security chief) after the Lamerlys deflect blame onto him. Jenny White, a sex worker raped by Drew 5 years earlier at his high school prom, had her police report buried by Paysen (then a cop). The Lamerlys have a pattern of covering up Drew's crimes and buying silence.

Jill Hoffman, fleeing domestic violence with stepson Tommy, is raped and murdered. Her husband Dan Hoffman is arrested and tried for the murder. No person is falsely accused then proven innocent; Dan is the actual suspect throughout. The episode focuses on domestic violence, custody issues, and protecting the child witness. No qualifying false suspect with public exposure and harm.

9-year-old beauty pageant contestant Cherie Lathan is found dead. Detectives pursue multiple suspects including her father, a teenage boy with disturbing stories, and a previously castrated sex offender before identifying Tommy Hedges as the perpetrator. Episode includes public confrontations of innocent people at work, home, and in front of family.

Charlie and Billy Baker commit a murder spree targeting wealthy couples. The episode does not feature anyone falsely accused who is later cleared. All suspects identified (Billy and Charlie Baker) are actually guilty. The father, Al Baker, is a victim of domestic violence by Charlie but is never formally accused of the murders. No innocent persons are publicly exposed or harmed by false accusations in this episode.

Joe Cappilla is accused of attempting to rape Cheryl Avery at a party. Cheryl kills Joe with a vase, claiming self-defense. Later revealed Cheryl is a pre-op transsexual woman who killed Joe to prevent him from exposing her secret to her boyfriend Eddie. Eddie, initially suspected as co-conspirator, is cleared but commits suicide after learning Cheryl's secret. The central 'false accusation' is Cheryl's rape claim against Joe—she later confesses she killed him to prevent exposure, not because of ongoing threat.

Michael Gardner was arrested and tried for four serial rapes. Three cases were dismissed for insufficient evidence. The fourth victim testified at trial. Gardner fled and committed a fifth rape-murder before being killed by his attorney. No innocent persons were publicly accused or harmed by false accusations in this episode. Gardner was the actual perpetrator throughout.

Jackie Landricks initially accuses Karl Sirett and points to James Randall after being raped and tied down. Investigation reveals multiple men who had sexual contact with Jackie's mother, Angie, at Tom Landricks' direction. Karl and James are publicly confronted and arrested, but DNA evidence eventually shows Tom Landricks orchestrated a scheme to impregnate his daughter using semen from men who had sex with his wife. Karl Sirett was publicly exposed at school and wrongfully suspected. James Randall was arrested and exposed before being cleared. Charles Eno was also wrongfully arrested. The case ultimately reveals Tom Landricks murdered a previous nanny, Karen Stenslin, when she refused to bear his child.

Episode involves Dr. Garret Lang running a fraudulent cloning operation targeting runaway teenage girls. Samantha Tassler dies from dehydration while being held captive by Paula Haggerty after threatening to expose the fraud. Jessica Morse and other girls were manipulated into believing they were carrying cloned babies, but Lang actually fertilized their eggs with his own sperm while defrauding grieving parents. No innocent persons are falsely accused with public exposure or material harm in this episode. The perpetrators (Lang and Haggerty) are the actual culprits, and while Lang attempts to shift blame to Haggerty during trial, this is defense strategy rather than a false accusation scenario. The initial armed robbery suspect who was shot is confirmed as the actual perpetrator (not a false suspect case).

15-year-old Chloe Dutton is raped and murdered after using a fake ID to get into a nightclub. The squad initially suspects hotel guest Zane Stark (whose Jaguar was used), then zeroes in on three wealthy young men (Andrew Kenworthy, Davis Harrington, Seth Wolfford III) and hotel valet Mitch Wilkens (posing as 'Max Van Horn'). All four participated in the gang rape. Seth is charged with murder based on evidence planted by Mitch. Detectives later discover Mitch is actually Eric Wayne Proctor, a convicted child-killer released from juvenile detention. The real killer is revealed to be Mitch/Eric, who framed Seth. Zane Stark is publicly accused at his hotel and interrogated despite being innocent.

Annika Bergeron, a pregnant artist, is kidnapped in what initially appears to be a carjacking by a serial rapist. The investigation reveals she was targeted specifically. Daniel Lester, her ex-boyfriend and the baby's father, is arrested and confesses to hiring the kidnapper. However, it's ultimately revealed that Melinda Granville, Daniel's fiancée, orchestrated the kidnapping out of jealousy and fear that Annika's baby would ruin her relationship with Daniel. Daniel falsely confessed to protect Melinda. Annika dies after giving birth, but the baby survives.

Two basketball players are murdered at a school gym. Joe Blaine, a 13-year-old student, is initially treated as a victim/witness but is later revealed to be the actual shooter. The episode focuses on Joe's culpability versus the pharmaceutical company's role in providing unsolicited Aptril (an antidepressant) that may have triggered his psychotic episode. Derek Fowler and George Waddell are investigated as suspects but later cleared. George admits to giving Joe the gun but claims it was unloaded.

Dr. Greta Heints, a psychiatrist specializing in treating sex offenders, is found unconscious in a crack house. The squad initially suspects Benny Ralsay (a civilly committed rapist she released) and Robert Logan (her law student patient). Benny is publicly exposed, loses his job, and is re-committed despite being innocent of the attack. Robert Logan is also publicly exposed and humiliated in court. The actual perpetrator is Christina Logan (Robert's sister), who attacked Dr. Heints in retaliation for inappropriate therapy techniques.

A woman (Melody Quinn) is run over and beaten to death in what appears to mimic a violent video game. Initially, Larry Tauber is identified as the sole suspect based on forensic evidence (his car, DNA, apartment, computer). He is publicly implicated but later revealed to have been a patsy for two teenagers, Garrett Perle and Louise Karnaki, who actually committed the murder. Tauber, manipulated and guilt-ridden, commits suicide before being formally charged. The episode tracks the false accusation and Tauber's resulting death.

A newborn is found dead in a sewer, and her mother Brianna Morris is found dead in her apartment. Investigation initially targets adoptive parents Ron and Kelly Wolcott, then dermatologist Dr. Archibald Newlands who Brianna claimed was the father. Newlands' DNA matches a 1998 child rape case (statute expired). He later faked his paternity test using another patient's blood. Newlands is murdered before trial. The real pedophile (whose blood Newlands used) is still at large and abducts another child.

Kevin Walker, a paranoid schizophrenic living in a grocery store basement, kidnapped 5-year-old Adam Forbes believing the boy was his own son 'Tate.' He murdered store owner Lester Hale and stabbed assistant manager Emilio Vasquez when they tried to stop him. While Kevin is clearly guilty of the crimes, the episode focuses on police misconduct: Dr. Huang medicated Kevin without consent to facilitate interrogation at Det. Stabler's urging. This constitutes coercion. Huang threatens to testify for the defense, which would destroy Stabler's credibility. ADA Novak pleads Kevin out to prevent the coercion from going on the record. The episode examines the ethical line between saving a victim and violating a suspect's rights. Kevin is proven guilty, not innocent—there are no false suspects who qualify for inclusion in person_rows.

Jennifer Fulton is assaulted at her restaurant. She initially identifies Leon Ardilles, an underage drinker previously cited at her bar, as her attacker. Leon is publicly confronted by police, arrested for trespass, and faced at gunpoint. Jennifer later recants, revealing her estranged husband Craig was the actual attacker. The episode focuses on subsequent legal battles over Jennifer's pregnancy and drinking, but Leon qualifies as a falsely accused person who suffered public exposure and police threats.

James Reed, a former poster-boy for the ex-gay ministry ReGenesis, is murdered by his secret boyfriend Ian Tate's father, Dr. Roger Tate. Dr. Tate killed Reed after discovering him in bed with Ian. Ian initially confessed to protect his father, but was not actually guilty. Ian was attacked by his father the night of the murder and went to the ER, establishing his alibi. While Ian falsely confessed, he does not qualify for inclusion as he was never publicly accused or exposed—he voluntarily confessed to protect his father, and was quickly cleared once evidence implicated Dr. Tate. No innocent person suffered public exposure or harm from false accusation in this episode.

Horace Gorman, a wealthy man who kidnapped and raped multiple women in a dungeon, is castrated by victim Hilary Barclay and later murdered by Hilary's mother Juliet. A homeless man named Samuel/Samael is briefly suspected due to being found with Gorman's severed genitals, but he's quickly understood to be mentally ill and not the perpetrator. Detective Olivia Benson is briefly implicated by the defense as creating reasonable doubt, but she was never formally accused or publicly exposed. No innocent person suffers public accusation-related harm in this episode.

Toddler Lucy Prichard is found unconscious in a park. SVU investigates multiple suspects including a photographer (Dennis Papillion), private investigator (Ronny Ickles), nanny Veronica Nash, nanny Sarah Rendell, and Evelyn's boyfriend Drew Farmer. Medical evidence ultimately points to the mother, Evelyn Prichard. Multiple innocent people experienced workplace exposure, public confrontation, and reputational harm during the investigation.

Michael Baxter escapes prison after being convicted of raping his ex-girlfriend's son Lee. He kidnaps Lee to force him to reveal the truth. DNA retesting reveals Baxter was innocent—the actual rapist was Lee's cousin Jeremy, who was 11 at the time of the incident. Lee falsely identified Baxter to protect Jeremy and avoid losing his mother's attention. Baxter spent 10 years in prison for a crime he didn't commit.

Tyler Henry, a Tau Omega fraternity pledge master, is found murdered at a sewage treatment plant. Initial investigation focuses on Chloe Spiers (whose topless video Tyler posted online) and her father Vernon (who previously assaulted Tyler). Both are cleared. The real killer is Will Caray, a former pledge who confesses to murdering Tyler after being raped during initiation. The case shifts to prosecuting Rob Sweeney for the rape. Nathan Angeli (another pledge) initially cooperates but recants after being re-invited to the fraternity. Transcript ends before resolution.

Sean Webster murdered Mira Elbisi and Tariq Assad in hate crimes, burning them alive. Mira's husband Elbisi was initially suspected and publicly questioned/exposed as a potential domestic violence perpetrator before being cleared. The episode primarily examines Webster's insanity defense based on genetic predisposition to violence.

Caitlin Lamarck is killed after being shoved into a mirror at a party by Jill (who wanted revenge for Caitlin's published 'lay list'). ME discovers Caitlin was also raped, which leads to paramedic Clark Tinta, who has been raping unconscious female patients. His partner Mike O'Doole covered for him while stealing from homes. No false accusation victims meeting our criteria appear in this episode - all suspects are either guilty or cleared privately without public exposure/harm.

Shannon Coyle, 16, is found murdered. Investigation reveals she was pregnant via incest—her boyfriend Aidan Connor is also her half-brother because their father Jason Connor led a double life as 'Barry Coyle.' Multiple suspects are accused, publicly exposed, and later cleared: choir teacher Steve Abruzzo (accused of murdering Shannon after alleged sexual misconduct); Aidan Connor (accused of murdering Shannon and his father); Brian Coyle (accused of incest/murder by his own mother in a public confrontation); and Susan Coyle (accused of murdering Jason Connor). Debra Connor ultimately confesses to killing Jason.

Episode focuses on homeschooled children whose mother's paranoia leads to one son killing the other. No false accusations of sex crimes occur. The case centers on child abuse, murder, and maternal manipulation rather than wrongful sexual assault allegations.

Emily Sullivan, 16, is murdered by three of her female classmates in a prolonged torture/killing. SVU initially suspects Agnes Linsky (a bullying victim) and her family, bringing them in for questioning and exposing them publicly before determining the actual killers were Emily's friends Brittany, Andrea, and Paige. Lukas Croft (23-year-old actor Emily dated) is also briefly suspected. Agnes had been tormented by Emily for years; her brother Troy assaults Brittany in retaliation but neither Agnes nor Troy killed Emily.

6-year-old Jamie Semple dies after being smothered. Sam Dufoy is initially accused and confesses, but is later revealed to be innocent. His wife Lori-Ann is the actual killer. Sam was publicly accused, arrested, and confessed under pressure to protect Lori-Ann. Father Hendry was also initially suspected of crushing Jamie during a prayer session but was innocent of causing death. Mariel Plummer (ACS social worker) faced criminal charges for child endangerment and record tampering; found not guilty of endangerment but lost her job and faced public crucifixion before suicide.

12-year-old JJ Ostilow makes violent threats online, leading to police raid and psychiatric evaluation. He discloses being molested by Billy Tripley, wealthy toy company owner, 3 years prior at a sleepover. Parents had signed $4M nondisclosure agreement. Billy Tripley is arrested and publicly perp-walked. JJ later recants under apparent parental pressure to protect settlement. Separately, 9-year-old April claims Tripley molested her at his house. Investigation reveals April's grandmother Nora fabricated April's leukemia diagnosis (mercury poisoning instead) and likely fabricated the molestation claim. Billy Tripley appears to have been falsely accused by April/Nora, but JJ's original accusation (before recantation) appears credible based on specific identifying details. Episode ends ambiguously but Warner's discovery suggests April's entire story was fabricated.

ADA Jeff York is found murdered in his car in circumstances staged to look like a sex crime involving a prostitute. The squad initially pursues transvestite prostitute Keisha Brown based on fingerprints, but she's cleared when her DNA doesn't match evidence at the scene. The actual killer is Andy Abbott, York's colleague and secret lover, who strangled York during an argument about their relationship. Keisha Brown was publicly accused but later proven innocent.

Prof. Javier Vega, a criminology professor and reformed ex-con, is wrongly accused and convicted of murdering his student/girlfriend Rebecca Wheeler. Evidence was planted by Kyle Luhrmann (Rebecca's research partner) to frame Vega. Vega's past conviction made him a target. He was publicly arrested, tried, convicted, imprisoned, and relapsed into heroin use before being cleared. Another suspect, Rudy Lemcke (a recovering addict and parolee), was also coercively interrogated and falsely confessed before detectives realized their error.

Christina Nerrit is found handcuffed with a plastic bag over her head. Detectives initially investigate as a sexual assault, pursuing Brooks Harmon (her boss/affair partner) as a suspect after surveillance footage and medical evidence point to him. Later revealed Christina attempted suicide, with assistance from Amy Solwey via an online suicide website. Brooks Harmon was publicly accused and interrogated before being cleared. Christina later dies from insulin injection in hospital, leading to Amy Solwey's prosecution for assisted suicide and eventually murder.

Gary DeVaal, a home healthcare nurse, is accused of murdering Donna Brooks and other elderly patients after being fired for theft. Detectives arrest him based on RDH nursing logs with his signature. Forensic analysis reveals his signature was forged via cut-and-paste Xerox method. DeVaal was set up by Emma Spevak, who actually committed the murders and framed both DeVaal and her brother Matt. DeVaal suffers arrest and interrogation despite being innocent. The true killer is Emma Spevak, who murdered multiple elderly women including her own mother.

Two mothers accused of poisoning daughters. Karen Campbell acquitted of attempted murder but later murders Alexis. Rosalin Silvo wrongfully convicted due to medical misdiagnosis of genetic disease as antifreeze poisoning; conviction later vacated. Judge Taft's bias and procedural violations central to both cases.

Principal Meredith Rice molests 12-year-old Shane Madden and kidnaps him. She is arrested after being caught. A brain tumor is discovered and removed. Doctors argue the tumor caused the behavior and she's no longer a threat. Episode ends before resolution of criminal charges. No innocent people are accused - Rice is the actual perpetrator. Wade Donato, the toilet cam voyeur who captured the assault, is arrested for video voyeurism but is not accused of the molestation itself.

A fertility doctor (Dr. Stanley Norton) forged a consent form and implanted Michele Osborne's embryo into Sarah Branson without consent. Michele discovered the biological truth and hired private investigators (Peter Carson and Kenneth Pratt) to recover her genetic daughter Patty. When that failed, Michele kidnapped Patty herself. No one is falsely accused of a sex crime in this episode—the case involves kidnapping/attempted kidnapping charges where the defendant is actually guilty (Michele) or working on her behalf (the PIs). Dr. Norton committed fraud/forgery related to IVF procedures, not a sex crime. The central conflict is a custody/parental rights dispute arising from medical malpractice, not a false accusation of sexual offense.

SVU investigates when two children are found abandoned. The search for their missing mother Jiao Wu leads to a human smuggling operation run by Ricky Yao. During the investigation, detectives question Howard Kendall (Jiao's ex-fiancé) at his workplace on Wall Street, publicly exposing him to colleagues as a suspect before clearing him. The episode focuses on the exploitation of undocumented Chinese immigrants by snakeheads (human smugglers), not wrongful accusations, but Kendall qualifies as a person harmed by public accusation despite being innocent.

Teen actress Jessie Dawning is raped in her trailer. Initial investigation focuses on executive producer Franco Marquez who faked DNA test results to hide his marriage to the 16-year-old. Danny Spencer, a 16-year-old fan influenced by shock jock BJ Cameron's show, is arrested and eventually pleads guilty. Franco Marquez is falsely suspected but cleared when evidence points to Danny. His public exposure includes workplace confrontation and revelations about his illegal marriage to Jessie.

A copycat serial killer mimics the 1970s-80s serial killer RDK. The squad initially suspects the original clockmaker Rupert Kilmore based on the killer's use of his name, publicly confronting him at his business. Kilmore is innocent and was targeted by the real killer (Humphrey Becker, a newspaper researcher) as part of an elaborate game. The squad executes a very public confrontation at Kilmore's workplace with customers and his employee present, causing exposure and likely reputational harm.

16-year-old Tandi McCain is found bound with duct tape, claims rape by uniformed men. SVU initially suspects army cadets from a nearby party. Four cadets are publicly named/questioned; one (Joseph Eglee) is chased into traffic by a mob and hospitalized. Videotape surfaces showing Tandi voluntarily at the party, drinking. Tandi recants on national TV. Investigation pivots to stepfather Ronald McCain (handprints at scene, prior abuse allegation), then to Tandi's employer Mike Tucker. Throughout, multiple innocent people are publicly accused, named in press, and harmed.

Billy Turner, a registered sex offender, is publicly accused of kidnapping and murdering 5-year-old Henry Morton. His apartment is searched, he's held for hours, and vigilante Malcolm Wolinsky organizes a public protest outside his residence calling him a 'pervert' and demanding he be removed from the neighborhood. Billy is later proven innocent via alibi. The actual perpetrator was 13-year-old neighbor Jake O'Hara, who confessed to accidentally killing Henry to prevent being sent back to a camp.

Cult leader Eugene Hoff (alias Abraham Ophion) sexually abused children within his cult, resulting in multiple deaths. No wrongfully accused persons identified—all investigative focus remained on the actual perpetrator throughout. The case involved a mass death event, hostage situations, and the rescue of pregnant 12-year-old victim Melanie. Her mother Sarah and other cult members were detained but not falsely accused of crimes they didn't commit; they were legitimately investigated as potential accomplices/witnesses to child abuse and murder.

Myra Denning accuses her graduate school professor Ron Polikoff of rape. The case is ambiguous with conflicting narratives about consent. Both parties suffer public consequences during the investigation and trial. The transcript ends before the jury verdict is revealed, making definitive innocence determination impossible. Ron Polikoff is fired from his teaching position and loses faculty housing based on the accusation alone. The episode primarily explores the investigation's impact on both accuser and accused, with uncertain resolution.

A serial rapist targets physically vulnerable women (wheelchair user, woman with baby, woman on crutches) and kills one victim. Detectives arrest Thomas Mathers based on circumstantial evidence (Ford Taurus, cigarette smell, dirty nails, proximity to crimes, history of peeping). He is interrogated about rapes and murder. His homosexuality becomes central to interrogation theory (detectives/psychologist theorize he's a closeted gay man who rapes women due to self-loathing). He is publicly arrested at his mother's home. DNA evidence later exonerates him completely. No apology is shown in transcript.

Detective Fin Tutuola is shot during a bodega robbery and later vindicated by security footage showing he shot two armed teenagers in self-defense. While recovering, he investigates the disappearance of Tricia Knowles, a woman he encountered years earlier while working undercover Narcotics. He discovers she was murdered by drug dealers and her infant son is missing. The episode focuses on Fin's guilt over not helping Tricia years ago and his efforts to rescue her child from a meth lab operation. No sex crimes or false accusations are depicted.

Mark Dobbins, a gym teacher and coach at Chestnut Academy, was falsely accused of molesting three girls (Holly Purcell, Nicole, and Danielle). Holly was actually abused by Kevin Wilcox, a high school lacrosse player, but named Dobbins as 'the safest target' out of fear. Two other mothers coached their daughters into false accusations after hearing about Holly. Dobbins was publicly arrested at a football game, jailed, lost his job despite charges being dismissed, and was forced to sell his house and move. The actual perpetrator Kevin Wilcox confessed to raping Holly and murdering Laura Swift.

Luis Vega dies falling from a roof during a sexual assault. Initially suspected attacker Logan Stanton is publicly confronted at school; his twin Lindsay also publicly confronted at home. Both are innocent—Logan because he wasn't present, Lindsay because the assault was self-defense but she was assigned male at birth and DNA matched her 'brother.' The real case involves sex therapist Dr. Blair who subjected the twins to coercive sexual 'treatment' sessions involving pornography and staged sexual positioning as part of an experiment on gender identity.

Lucas Biggs, on death row in Virginia for a different child murder, is investigated for the 1980 murder of Jeffrey Ronsen. Detectives receive an anonymous tip leading to Jeffrey's remains. Biggs is interviewed and denies involvement. Evidence eventually reveals Deacon Brinn (himself a victim of Biggs' abuse as a child) killed Jeffrey. Later, Avery Shaw falsely confesses to killing Deacon to protect Julia Brinn, who actually killed her husband after discovering he'd molested their son Zeke. While Biggs was falsely suspected of Jeffrey's murder, there is no public exposure of this suspicion - investigation was contained to law enforcement. Avery's false confession is an attempt to protect Julia, but he was never publicly accused before his voluntary confession.

Melody Quinn is murdered in a hit-and-run attack that mirrors a violent video game sequence. Investigation initially focuses on Larry Tauber (whose car, apartment, and computer were used), but evidence reveals teenagers Garrett Perle and Louise Karnaki committed the murder while Tauber watched. Tauber commits suicide after receiving a threatening email from Garrett. Both teens are convicted of murder. Larry Tauber appears to have been manipulated/coerced by the teens and is cleared of the actual murder, though he was present and complicit.

Lisa Downey, 15, is murdered by porn producer Max Long after he learns she has HIV. During the investigation, several individuals are publicly accused or exposed: Lisa's father Tim Downey is suspected of killing both Lisa and Dr. Tanner; Andy Wall (Lisa's ex-boyfriend) is publicly confronted about domestic violence and the murder; Dr. Derek Tanner is publicly accused of statutory rape and questioned about murder before being killed by Angela Agnelli. Tim Downey is questioned in his workplace/public contexts and threatened by detectives. Andy Wall is publicly confronted at his college study group location.

Contract killer Liam Connors murders Elena and Jason Brevet, Sergio and Mrs. Montoya, and attempts to kill 8-year-old Antonio Montoya and ADA Alexandra Cabot. No innocent persons are falsely accused. The episode focuses on the squad pursuing the actual perpetrator and protecting witnesses. Detectives temporarily charge Connors with Alex Cabot's 'murder' to detain him (she's alive in Witness Protection), but this involves prosecutorial strategy rather than harming an innocent person—Connors is guilty of attempting to murder her.

Gordon Rickett, previously acquitted of murdering 11-year-old Dana MacNamara 14 years earlier, is arrested for murdering 12-year-old Kerry Lynn Palmer. The episode follows a 24-hour interrogation. Rickett is ultimately caught with another kidnapped girl in a basement, proving his guilt. No innocent persons are publicly accused or harmed by false accusations in this episode.

Episode involves abduction and murder of Kaley Sellers, a bike messenger who was auctioning her virginity online. Multiple false suspects were investigated, including ex-boyfriend Jake Ostrander and BiddingRoom bidder Harlan Beaumont, before discovering the actual perpetrators were Henry Palaver (using alias Sebastian Ballentine), a fake psychic with a criminal past, and his wife Carlene. Jake was publicly questioned and exposed, and Harlan was interrogated in his home.

Denise Eldridge accuses Justin Sharp of statutory rape. Justin is arrested for Denise's murder after she is killed. He is publicly arrested, transported, interrogated, and held in contempt of court. Evidence ultimately shows Carrie killed her mother in self-defense during abuse. Justin was innocent of murder but publicly accused and processed through the system before being cleared.

A woman is found dead with $5000 in her mouth. Investigation leads to a sex club and eventually to Gabriel Duvall, a wealthy eccentric computer programmer. The episode includes a wrongful arrest/questioning of Milan Jurgen, Nina's brother, who violently attacks ADA Casey Novak after blaming her for forcing his sister to testify about her rape. Milan is arrested for assaulting Novak but is innocent of the serial rapes. Gabriel Duvall is ultimately arrested for the rape-murder and serial rapes of undocumented women.

A woman (Sam Beavan) is sexually assaulted while her baby is thrown from a car. Investigation reveals drug dealing involving elderly Jenny Rogers and her daughter-in-law Carol. Jenny is initially accused of drug dealing and assault, later testifies her son Kevin murdered Carol, then recants under pressure. Kevin is arrested for murder but case dismissed after Jenny's perjury. Episode ends with Kevin arrested on drug charges to force him into treatment.

Leon Shragewitz, an observant Jewish butcher, is accused of murdering and dismembering his girlfriend Manette Combs after he witnessed her performing oral sex for money. He is confronted by detectives at his synagogue and arrested, but is later proven innocent when the medical examiner confirms Manette died from a broken neck in a subway fall (accidental death after Leon pushed her). Her body was then stolen from the morgue and dismembered by Russ Bianco for illegal organ trafficking. Leon's public arrest at his synagogue in front of his religious community constitutes exposure, and he was subject to coercive interrogation tactics.

Two NYPD officers serving in Army Reserve in Afghanistan—Tom Callahan and Wes Myers—commit violent acts against their wives after taking the anti-malaria drug Quinium. Both men experience psychosis, paranoia, hallucinations, and suicidal ideation as side effects. Callahan rapes his wife Jamie and later assaults his captain; Myers kills his wife Kendra and attempts suicide. SVU initially investigates Jamie Callahan's rape allegation, but the case evolves into an investigation of the military's knowing administration of a dangerous drug. No innocent persons are falsely accused of sex crimes in this episode—the perpetrators (Callahan and Myers) actually committed the violent acts, though under the influence of military-prescribed medication. The episode focuses on holding the Army/pharmaceutical company accountable rather than wrongful accusation dynamics.

This episode follows Ray Schenkel, a convicted rapist released on parole who becomes the primary suspect in a new rape. Detective Stabler goes undercover as a fellow sex offender parolee to get close to Ray. Ray ultimately kidnaps a woman and attempts to rape her, proving his guilt. There are no falsely accused innocent persons in this episode - Ray is actually guilty, and the undercover operation successfully prevents a rape and leads to his re-arrest. Kelly Browning, the initial victim at Port Authority, was genuinely raped (strongly implied to be by Ray based on MO match). No innocent persons suffered public exposure or harm from false accusations.

April Troost accuses Barclay Pallister of rape. DNA proves paternity. At trial, defense offers settlement which April initially accepts, undermining her credibility. She later dies in a staged car crash. Investigation reveals April was a con artist who drugged and sexually assaulted dozens of wealthy men to harvest sperm for sale. Barclay Pallister was falsely accused of rape; he was actually drugged and assaulted by April. He faced public trial, marriage dissolution, and reputational harm before being cleared when the truth emerged.

A 9-year-old Honduran girl named Maria calls 911 from a locked room where she's being held by a child pornographer. SVU traces the call through technological barriers and finds Richard Dwyer, the perpetrator. Maria is rescued alive from a shallow grave. No false suspects or wrongful accusations are depicted. The initial trace to cabbie Ricardo Garcia is resolved immediately when his actual daughter is confirmed safe. This episode contains no qualifying false accusation scenarios.

Luke Breslin is accused of assaulting his friend Pamela Sawyer at school. He is proven guilty (steroid-induced rage), not innocent. Pete Breslin (Luke's father) is not a suspect of the sexual assault. The episode involves no falsely accused persons who were later proven innocent. While Luke exhibited amnesia and psychiatric symptoms, he actually committed the assault against Pamela. The exposure and consequences to Luke were warranted. No qualifying person-rows.

Episode centers on murders of two HIV+ men (Robin Weller, Lydon Grant) staged by Gabriel Thomason as vigilante action against spread of 'killer strain' HIV via crystal meth/circuit party culture. King Henry/Henry Finello, MKS gang member, was arrested for assault/robbery at club but falsely suspected of the murders based on 'killer' graffiti matching his gang name. He was publicly accused of murder during interrogation but proven innocent when Gabriel confessed. Robin's father also made false accusation against Lydon Grant as violent boyfriend, but Lydon was victim not perpetrator.

A sniper kills one child and wounds two others at a public school playground.
