All three later cleared when Holly Schneider revealed as actual perpetrator who fabricated evidence to frame the judge and harm her roommate Meghan out of jealousy.

William Rand, CEO of a private military contractor, is drugged and assaulted by Donald O'Keeffe in retaliation for four Battle Tested Security employees gang-raping O'Keeffe's daughter Cory in Basra, Iraq. The case primarily involves O'Keeffe's vigilante justice and the SVU investigation uncovering corporate cover-up of Cory's rape. No innocent persons are falsely accused of sex crimes in this episode. Rand was actually assaulted (not falsely accused), and Cory was actually raped (not a false claim). The investigation focuses on exposing the guilty parties who evaded justice for four years.

Fred Sandow, a former documentary filmmaker turned reality TV producer, is accused of drugging and sexually assaulting aspiring actresses during auditions. The episode focuses on his arrest and the subsequent hostage situation created by his son Eddie, who has been groomed and manipulated by his father. While there are accusations against Sandow, the episode does not show anyone who is accused and later proven or strongly implied to be innocent. Sandow is consistently portrayed as guilty throughout, with physical evidence (DNA, Quaaludes in champagne, victim underwear found at scene) and multiple victims. Eddie Sandow takes hostages in response to his father's arrest but is not himself accused of the sexual crimes—his criminal actions (hostage-taking, shooting) occur on-screen as direct plot events, not false accusations. No qualifying false accusation cases are present in this episode.

Multiple innocent people are investigated and exposed before the truth emerges: Emmy Eckhouse orchestrated her parents' murder after being sexually abused by her father. Jimmy Vasquez (former housekeeper's brother) and Carmen Vasquez (housekeeper) become suspects, with Jimmy ultimately confessing to the shooting. Emmy's boyfriend Rob Fisher and his father are also investigated. Detective Rollins' gambling addiction subplot involves illegal bookies Murphy and McCourt, who are raided but turn out to be uninvolved in the murders.

SVU investigates a serial killer (Graham Winger/Brewster) who hunts and murders escorts on a wildlife preserve. All victims were genuinely victimized by the killer. No false accusations occur. The squad correctly identifies and confronts the actual perpetrator. No innocent persons are accused, exposed, or harmed by wrongful suspicion in this episode.

Simon Marsden is pulled over for a traffic violation with his fiancée Tracy and their two children. Officer finds one joint of marijuana (medical use for dental pain/appetite). Child Services removes children after home visit finds bruise on older child. Drug charge is dismissed due to unconstitutional search, but family court judge still denies return of children based on 'where there's smoke, there's fire' reasoning and Simon's past false rape accusation. In desperation, Simon and Tracy kidnap their own children from foster care, leading to arrest. Simon accepts plea deal requiring him to give up custody and live separately from family for 3 years in exchange for reduced charges.

Omar Pena was wrongfully convicted in 2004 for the rape and torture of Ariel Baskins based on a coerced confession containing a false detail (green vs. red scarf), victim misidentification, and witness misidentifications. He spent 8 years imprisoned. When the real rapist (Brazilian sailor Javier) committed an identical crime during Fleet Week 2013, DNA evidence and reinvestigation revealed Pena's innocence. The confession was obtained during a 9-hour interrogation where Detective Benson inadvertently fed Pena a false detail from a color-blind officer's evidence log. Six bar witnesses also misidentified Pena. Conviction vacated when true perpetrator arrested.

Christine Hartwell stages her own rape and kidnapping, falsely accusing delivery man Kevin Fahey. She later admits he raped her but evidence (video, testimony) shows consensual affair. Kevin is arrested, publicly tried, and spends time in custody. Previous delivery man Brad Hayes also publicly accused of affair during trial. Christine maintains innocence despite video evidence of consensual sex. Case ends in mistrial with 11-1 guilty vote. Both men face public exposure and legal consequences for consensual relationships Christine now claims were rape.

Stuart, obsessed with Leslie, commits serial rapes to create a crisis where he can be her hero. When Henry becomes romantically involved with Leslie, Stuart frames Henry by planting hair evidence in his car and falsely claiming he witnessed Henry rape Leslie on a rooftop. Henry is arrested and publicly exposed before being cleared. Stuart confesses to being the actual rapist.

A man posing as donor father Colin Barnes contacts and seduces multiple donor daughters. Dr. Colin Barnes is initially suspected but proven innocent. Three teenage girls (Cate Avery, Ashley R., Melissa) are questioned and undergo lineups. Philip Kelly is briefly investigated as a suspect. The actual perpetrator is Sean Albers, who impersonated Barnes to seduce the girls and kidnap Barnes' biological daughter Taylor.

Two teachers are falsely accused of sexual misconduct with student Luca Gabardelli. Rick Simms is first accused, beaten by Luca's father in a staged gay-bashing, then arrested and publicly humiliated. When that accusation falls apart, Joanne Parsons is accused and arrested. Both are later cleared when it's revealed the actual abuser is teacher Natalie Relais, who manipulated Luca into fabricating accusations as cover.

Episode involves the abduction and murder of Nina Raedo, whose leg was amputated by psychiatrist Dr. Hal Brightman. Multiple suspects were investigated and publicly questioned before identifying the actual perpetrator. Dr. Gene Brightman (the dentist brother) and Jess Hardwick (body modification artist) were both publicly accused/investigated before being cleared. Pablo (Nina's ex-boyfriend) was also publicly questioned. The actual perpetrator, Dr. Hal Brightman, confessed to amputating six women's legs over 11 years, with Nina dying from propofol overdose during her amputation.

A 16-year-old girl (Maggie Murphy) is found dead at a bachelor party for the police commissioner's son. Investigation reveals she was murdered via scopolamine overdose, part of an escort service war. Multiple wealthy/powerful men had sex with the underage victim. The transcript ends before resolution, so we cannot determine if anyone was definitively cleared of wrongdoing. Several people were questioned (Clayton Hannigan, Will Brady, Bart Ganzsel, Yuko the masseuse, Iris, Delia Wilson) but the incomplete transcript does not provide conclusive innocence determinations or clear public exposure consequences for any accused individuals. Episode requires full transcript for complete analysis.

Unable to analyze episode content due to missing transcript. Episode title 'Lost Reputation' suggests themes of reputational harm potentially relevant to false accusation tracking, but no data available to confirm presence of innocent suspects or public exposure consequences.

Unable to analyze episode content due to missing transcript. Episode title 'Above Suspicion' suggests potential themes of authority figures or persons in positions of trust being accused, but no specific details can be extracted without transcript content.

Talk show host Adam Cain is accused of raping author Jocelyn Paley twice. The case involves complex issues around consent, rough sex, and Jocelyn's revelation that she didn't actually write her BDSM-themed bestseller. Cain is ultimately convicted. No falsely accused innocent persons identified in this episode - the accused (Cain) is found guilty at trial.

Episode involves a sex trafficking ring run by Lou and Mikey Pappas. Jonas Dworkin is falsely accused of paying for sex after a car accident. The case becomes complicated when Homeland Security reveals connections to terrorism; the squad must delay the trafficking bust. Multiple trafficked women are involved (Anna, Pilar, Vika, Sofia). Vika is murdered. Sofia turns out to be a terrorist sleeper agent posing as a trafficking victim. Dworkin is publicly accused and his wife is threatened to be contacted, causing work/family exposure despite being innocent of the sex crime accusation.

Seven-year-old Wyatt Morris is abducted from a subway platform. Investigation uncovers connection to 1999 disappearance of Hector Rodriguez, whose body is found buried in concrete in a building owned by Wyatt's grandfather. Lewis Hodda, an arsonist/troubleshooter for the Morris family, is arrested for both abductions. The episode also features auxiliary officer Stephen Lomatin, who becomes a suspect due to his obsessive focus on missing children cases but is cleared. Hector's father was wrongly blamed for 13 years for taking his son back to the Dominican Republic.

14-year-old Emily Culphers is kidnapped from a frat party by a predator (Peter) who uses social engineering and malware to target victims. Her older sister Taylor (15) is arrested for statutory rape after being photographed topless with a 21-year-old frat brother (Merc). SVU tracks the kidnapper through Darknet child pornography sites and recovers Emily, discovering Peter had victimized multiple girls over five years with help from Wendi/Jane Kalreiss, herself a former victim. No persons are falsely accused of the kidnapping or sex crimes - the investigation correctly identifies Peter as the perpetrator throughout. Merc is guilty of statutory rape. Taylor is a victim, not accused. No qualifying false accusation cases.

A baby is kidnapped from a playground. Initial suspect is a registered sex offender (Allen Clyde) who is later cleared when video shows a woman (Dia Nobile) took the baby. Investigation reveals fraudulent adoption/surrogacy paperwork orchestrated by lawyer Wendell Feeney. Dia claims baby's father is law school dean Kent Webster, who denies relationship. Episode ends with Gillian Webster (Kent's terminally ill wife) confessing to murdering Dia to protect her daughter Hannah, though evidence suggests Hannah may be the actual killer.

Episode centers on institutional cover-up of sexual abuse at elite private school. Harold Lassiter commits suicide after receiving letter from victim 'Curt.' Investigation reveals systemic abuse by multiple teachers over 30+ years. No false suspects - all accused teachers were actual abusers. Focus shifts from criminal prosecution (statute expired) to forcing school acknowledgment and apology. Key evidence: board chair Brett Forrester knew of complaints, wrote dismissive response to parent, and own son Nathan was victimized by Strepek. Episode ends with school publicly acknowledging abuse culture. Walter Tompkins confesses to consensual relationships with 17-18 year old students but is used strategically in legal argument, not prosecuted. No innocent persons falsely accused or publicly exposed in this episode.

Episode centers on NYPD/FBI manhunt for spree killer Craig Rasmussen, who maintains 20-year relationship with sex worker Jeannie Kerns. No persons are falsely accused of sex crimes. Episode ends with intervention convincing Jeannie to enter rehab. No false accusation plotline present.

Sam Randall, a parolee, attempts to save Father Chris Shea from a violent assault and is wrongly arrested for carjacking and assault. Two neighborhood vigilantes beat the priest believing he was a pedophile. Sam is publicly arrested, remanded to custody through Christmas, and his parole is threatened. The detectives eventually prove Sam's innocence through security footage, forensics, witness statements, and Father Shea's testimony identifying Sam as his savior. Father Shea himself becomes a suspect due to being alone with a young girl but is later proven innocent. The actual molester is revealed to be Monsignor Menendez, who abused Angelica Rodriguez ten years prior.

Jessie Sturgis is raped by Michael Provo, a confidential informant for the Suffolk County DA. When she reports the rape, Provo frames her for murdering her boyfriend Tommy Bandolce to discredit her. Multiple witnesses are coerced by Provo into giving false testimony. The episode reveals Provo's pattern of abusing his law enforcement connections to threaten and manipulate victims and witnesses.

Jeremy Jones, a gay man, targets closeted gay men in bars, luring them to hotels where he robs and assaults them. One victim, Harry Dunleavy, dies of a heart attack during the assault. While the episode involves multiple victims and complex dynamics around closeted sexuality, there are no innocent people falsely accused. All identified suspects (Jeremy Jones and his husband Mason Clark) are actually involved in the crimes. The victims (Murphy, Armstrong, Jackson, Dunleavy) are victims throughout, not falsely accused perpetrators.

Gymnastics coach Alexei Belyakov is stabbed by janitor Johnny Dubcek after Dubcek witnesses Belyakov filming/touching students during training. Dubcek (himself an abuse survivor) misinterprets legitimate coaching as abuse. SVU discovers Belyakov is innocent and that both Dubcek and death row inmate Reggie Rhodes were actually abused decades earlier by camp counselor Martin Schultz. Investigation pivots to Schultz (arrested for child porn possession) and prosecutorial misconduct in Rhodes's murder trial. Belyakov suffers public accusation, investigation, and stabbing despite innocence.

Brian Traymor is arrested for five rape/murders from 1986-1988 based on DNA match and FBI Agent Dana Lewis's interrogation. He confesses to four murders but consistently denies the fifth (Kira Stanger). Investigation reveals Lewis had a personal relationship with Kira's fiancé Noah and was the actual killer. Traymor was coerced into confessing to a crime he didn't commit. He was publicly arrested, transported across state lines, and subjected to 15+ hours of interrogation including coercive tactics by Lewis who knew he was innocent of Kira's murder.

Amanda Rollins is falsely accused of murder after shooting Jeff Parker. Her sister Kim set her up by taking out life insurance, luring Jeff to the apartment, and falsely crying rape. Kim then cooperated with IAB against Amanda, leading to her arrest. Amanda was publicly arrested, booked, and had to post $250K bail before being exonerated when Kim confessed to the scheme on a recording.

Music star Caleb Bryant assaults his girlfriend Micha Green in a recording studio. He is arrested and charged but uses his platform to manipulate public opinion and pressure Micha. When music producer Brass (who was protecting Micha) is murdered at a club, Micha initially agrees to testify that Caleb killed him, but recants under pressure. She flees with Caleb to Bermuda where she is found dead. No innocent persons are falsely accused in this episode; Caleb is guilty of assault, likely guilty of murder, and appears responsible for Micha's death. This is a domestic violence case where the perpetrator is never wrongly accused.

Detective Brian Cassidy is accused of raping a former prostitute, Heather Riggs, four years earlier when he was undercover. The accusation surfaces just before he's set to testify against pimp Bart Ganzel. Heather claims Cassidy raped her during his undercover work, describing a scar on his thigh. The case goes to trial with public exposure in court. Eventually, Heather's boyfriend Bobby Navarro is revealed to have visited Ganzel in prison, and the accusation is proven fabricated for financial gain. Heather recants, admitting Cassidy didn't touch her and they just talked. The charges are dropped. Separately, Detective Amaro is exposed in court regarding a past undercover relationship, revealing he has a nine-year-old son he never knew about.

Avery Jordan, a sports reporter, reports being raped by her cameraman Rick Purcell. The case goes to trial where Purcell represents himself and cross-examines the victim. Jury acquits him of rape but convicts on stalking charges. Purcell then sues for custody of the child conceived during the rape. Throughout the episode, there is no indication that Purcell is innocent—the acquittal appears based on reasonable doubt and jury compromise, not proof of innocence. No other suspects are pursued or cleared. Episode ends with Avery fleeing the country with her baby to escape court-ordered visitation.

Five-year-old Ruby Mesner presents at school with a cracked rib and bruising. The nanny Irina Janovic is initially accused of pushing Ruby down the stairs based on the older brother Henry's testimony. Detectives publicly confront Irina at her workplace, threaten her with INS consequences, and she is detained. Henry later admits he pushed Ruby as an 'experiment.' Irina is cleared but faced workplace exposure, immigration threats, and police detention as an undocumented worker accused of child abuse.

College freshman Lindsay Bennett is gang-raped at a fraternity party. A previous victim, Renee Clark, had reported rape by the same perpetrator a year earlier. Both cases involve institutional failure by Tompkins Square University to properly investigate or support victims. The episode focuses on Travis Holmes, Wesley Grimes, and Carter Pressman as perpetrators who ultimately face charges. No falsely accused innocent persons are identified in this transcript. Lindsay tragically dies by suicide. The school's dean and security director are charged as accessories for obstruction and cover-up of multiple sexual assaults.

Gabby Shaw is gang-assaulted at a club. Initial suspects include six men caught fleeing the scene and security guard Frank Patterson, who Gabby IDs as an attacker. Frank, an Iraq/Afghanistan veteran with PTSD, initially confesses but later clarifies he was trying to protect Gabby during a flashback. The actual conspiracy was orchestrated by Gabby's ex-boyfriend Alec Peters and 'friends' Brit and Jake, who hired Louis to expose her breasts as a prank. Frank is publicly accused and arrested before being cleared. Louis is also falsely accused of assault when he only participated in the top-sharking prank, not the gang assault.

Detective Rollins is shot during a perp walk. Investigation reveals a sniper targeting people connected to an old narcotics case. Luis Montero, Fin's former partner, falsely confesses to protect his daughter Gloria, who is the actual shooter seeking revenge for her family's suffering after Luis was shot saving Fin's life 15 years earlier. Gloria is ultimately arrested in a hostage standoff.

Multiple people were investigated as suspects in Ariel Randolph's assault and death. Two teens (Jaspar and Todd) were initially questioned for being found with her body. Sound engineer Phil Desapio was arrested after evidence showed he was with Ariel the night of the assault, lied to police, and had her DNA under his fingernails from her scratching him. Santiago Morales and Charles 'Charley' Landry were also investigated after photos showed them partying with Ariel. All were eventually cleared when a homeless sex offender living in the park was found with Ariel's belongings and forensic evidence matched him. Phil Desapio experienced the most significant harm: he was arrested, interrogated, and his romantic interest in Ariel exposed despite being innocent of the assault. Charles Landry's secret cross-dressing lifestyle was exposed during the investigation, threatening his marriage and job.

Serial predator William Lewis is arrested for lewdness, then rapes and tortures photographer Alice Parker for 18 hours. Parker dies of heart attack before trial. Lewis's defense attorney gets a mistrial by proving DNA lab cross-contamination. No false suspects; Lewis is guilty of all crimes. Episode ends with Lewis confronting Benson at her home after being released on bail.

Unable to analyze episode content due to missing transcript. Episode metadata indicates Season 15, Episode 1 titled 'Surrender Benson' but no dialogue, scenes, or character information available for tagging innocent persons falsely accused or exposed.

Tony Minetti is falsely accused of kidnapping and imprisoning women in his estranged mother's house. He is publicly arrested, interrogated, and explicitly states his mother must have 'set him up.' He is proven innocent when detectives discover Michael Williams impersonated him for years. Williams actually committed the crimes. Tony experienced public arrest and interrogation based on ownership records, but was quickly cleared when his alibi (20 years estrangement, gay identity his mother rejected) was verified.

Episode centers on a serial rapist case where 16-year-old honor student Mehcad Carter is wrongly identified by two victims and publicly suspected by SVU before being fatally shot by celebrity chef Jolene Castille. Willie Taylor is later arrested as the actual rapist. Mehcad was innocent, walking home from basketball, but was subjected to public accusation, victim identifications, media coverage, and ultimately killed based on racial profiling and mistaken identity. The episode explores themes of false identification, racial bias in policing, and the consequences of wrongful accusations.

SVU investigates compstat manipulation at the 12th precinct where officers West and Quinn are revealed to be serial rapists who assault drunk women while on duty. Officer Quinn also covered for West by making fake 911 calls. The precinct had been intimidating rape victims into dropping charges. Officer Groves, who tried to expose the corruption, was forcibly institutionalized to discredit him. Detective Cassidy goes undercover and is nearly killed when his cover is blown. No innocent persons accused of sex crimes are identified in this episode - the officers West and Quinn are guilty, not falsely accused.

Sarah Walsh reports being raped after attending an underground party. Initially she believes her previous rapist Michael Wedmore is responsible, but investigation reveals Cameron Tyler, a wealthy tech entrepreneur, drugged and assaulted her. Tyler is also discovered to have raped Nicole (Sarah's friend) at a July 4th party, plus multiple other women. Tyler pleads guilty to four counts of aggravated sexual assault. No persons are shown to be falsely accused then later cleared; Wedmore is investigated but quickly ruled out via alibi and GPS data without public exposure or consequences.

Mayoral candidate Alex Munoz's close friend Eddie Garcia is accused of attempted rape by Lindsay Anderson. Investigation reveals Lindsay is a serial extortionist targeting wealthy/powerful married men. Eddie was innocent of rape, but was acting as a bag man delivering hush money payments for Alex to multiple women. The case pivots to Alex's own misconduct (sexting with minor, patronage bribes), leaving Eddie as a cooperating witness. Eddie was publicly accused of attempted rape at his home in front of his family and was arrested, held overnight, and charged before being cleared when the real story emerged.

Jackie Walker, a pre-K music teacher and vocal coach on American Diva, is falsely accused of child sexual abuse by two teenage girls (Brooke and Rachel) who coach their younger brothers to lie after Jackie dropped them as students. Walker is publicly arrested, perp-walked, loses his TV job, and is incarcerated at Rikers unable to make bail. Though charges are eventually dismissed, his career and reputation are destroyed. The detectives conducted a public confrontation at his workplace and pursued the case aggressively despite his consistent denials.

Coast Guard Ensign Amelia Albers is gang-raped by her C.O. and three fellow officers. Initially she mentions two Mexican cooks from the bar, who are briefly suspected but proven innocent. The cooks were publicly confronted and one fled when police arrived. Episode focuses on military culture silencing rape victims and victim-blaming; the innocent cooks are secondary but qualify as harmed by false accusation with public exposure.

Gene Fierstein is accused of rape by Lena Olson, whom he was having a consensual affair with while engaged to Melissa Blume. The D.A. declines to prosecute due to conflicting evidence (consensual sex earlier, suggestive texts). Gene later falls to his death from Lena's rooftop after oral sex. The investigation reveals Lena manipulated Detective Rollins (through sponsor Nate) to establish a rape claim, then murdered Gene. Gene is ultimately shown to be innocent of rape; Lena fabricated/exaggerated the claim as part of premeditated murder. Gene's fiancée Melissa learns of the affair and rape accusation before his death. Gene experienced public exposure to his fiancée and significant reputational/relationship harm from the false rape accusation before being murdered.

This episode depicts the trial of William Lewis for kidnapping and assaulting Detective Olivia Benson. Lewis represents himself and attempts to portray the incident as consensual. There are no false accusations of innocent parties in this episode - the trial concerns the actual perpetrator (Lewis) who is found guilty of kidnapping and assault but not guilty of attempted murder/rape. The housekeeper Viva Nunez and her daughter are witnesses but are not accused of any crime. This episode does not contain qualifying person-rows for the dataset.

Detective Amaro shoots 14-year-old Yusef Barre during a foot chase, believing the teen is armed and has shot Officer McKenna. Investigation reveals McKenna accidentally shot herself and Yusef was unarmed. Amaro is arrested and charged with assault, facing trial. The case becomes highly publicized with media coverage, protests by Reverend Curtis, and political pressure from new mayor/commissioner. Grand jury ultimately declines to indict (10-8 vote). Episode focuses on Amaro's legal ordeal, not on Yusef as wrongly accused, but Yusef qualifies as a person harmed by false accusation of being an armed cop-shooter.

Clare Wilson raped by Prosecutor Masconi at Perry's strip club. Tommy and Jeff accused of sexual assault but innocent - they only witnessed Clare after rape. Masconi and Perry weaponize legal system to silence Clare via fraud charges and abusive juvenile detention. Investigation exposes corruption ring involving judge ownership via blackmail. Dolan commits suicide. Tommy and Jeff qualify as false suspects with private exposure only (severity 1), excluded from person_rows per rubric.

Avery Capshaw, 16, is gang-raped by three BX9 members who force her boyfriend Manny Montero to watch. Initially Manny is treated as a suspect/accomplice. He is publicly arrested, interrogated, and held in custody. Later it emerges he joined the gang under duress to protect his grandmother and knew the gang was coming but froze rather than calling for help. He is proven not to have participated in the rape itself. He is publicly arrested in his neighborhood, exposed at school (missing classes noted by admin), and his role is revealed to Avery. He ultimately provides testimony to protect Avery, then is murdered in Rikers before trial. Avery initially thought he was dead and attempted suicide by jumping off a building. The episode depicts Manny as initially suspected, publicly exposed, then cleared of the rape charge itself but implicated in negligent failure to protect, ending in his murder.

Episode centers on a re-homing case where an adoptive mother secretly gives away her 7-year-old adopted son Nicky to strangers she found online. The child ends up with registered sex offenders who traffic in children for webcam exploitation. No one is falsely accused of a sex crime in this episode. The primary legal issues involve child endangerment, trafficking, and exploitation by Roger and Alexa Pearson, who are actually guilty of the crimes they're arrested for. Lisa Moore faces potential charges for giving away her child without her husband's consent and filing a false missing persons report, but she is not accused of a sex crime.

Comedian Josh Galloway makes rape jokes at a college show. Student Renee Clark protests and is later assaulted by two fans (Sean Brady and Chad Smith) who are arrested. Student Carly Rydell accuses Galloway of rape after attending his show; he is arrested and tried. The trial reveals Carly was heavily intoxicated and a video surfaces showing her flirting with Galloway earlier. Galloway testifies the sex was consensual. Separately, activist Renee Clark secretly records Galloway attempting to rape her in a sting operation. Galloway ultimately pleads guilty to sexual assault charges and becomes a registered sex offender. No innocent persons are shown to be falsely accused - the accused parties (Sean, Chad, and Josh) are all guilty of the offenses charged or plead to.

Cedric Jones, an 18-year-old football recruit, is sexually assaulted by Hudson University football players during a recruiting weekend. After being pranked/assaulted (blindfolded and serviced by a male cheerleader while thinking it was female hostesses), he flees to a gay bar where he assaults a patron. Initially arrested for gay bashing, investigation reveals he was the victim of rape by deception and hazing orchestrated by the team. Eddie Thorpe, his host, is also revealed as a rape victim from freshman hazing ordered by Coach Becker. The investigation uncovers systemic sexual assault and hazing on the team, leading to arrests of players and the coach.

Detective Rollins becomes compromised by a gambling debt at an illegal club run by organized crime. The criminals force her to assist with crimes including removing a gun from evidence and tampering with DNA evidence. A Brazilian diplomat's wife (Mrs. Guarana) is raped by Carlos Riva as a 'message' to her husband over his gambling debts. Rollins is revealed to have been working undercover for Lt. Declan Murphy (Vice) after being caught. Mrs. Guarana is the primary innocent victim - she is raped as retaliation for her husband's behavior, not for anything she did. Her husband Marcelo is also victimized through the assault on his wife and the home invasion, though his gambling debts created the situation.

A Muslim woman, Heba Salim, initially claims she was raped by strangers in Central Park in a hate crime. Investigation reveals she was actually raped by her brother's boss Elias Kemp Jr. and his colleague Mike Sullivan in Kemp's office. She fabricated the Central Park story to protect her family's honor. Columnist Jimmy MacArthur writes articles claiming she's a liar before learning the truth. The actual perpetrators Elias Kemp Jr. and Mike Sullivan are guilty and prosecuted. No innocent person is falsely accused or publicly harmed by wrongful accusation in this episode.

Episode centers on Jenny Aschler, a victim of severe childhood sexual abuse whose images were distributed online. The case involves her current husband Gary's spousal rape and her neglect charge for leaving daughter Maddie alone. Gary confesses to marital rape believing it's legal. Jenny undergoes therapy and eventually secures restitution from men convicted of possessing her childhood abuse images. No false accusations of innocent people occur in this episode - Gary admits to rape, Jenny's stepfather Jerry Dobbs (deceased) committed documented child sexual abuse, and men convicted of possessing child pornography are guilty. The episode explores victim trauma and legal restitution rather than wrongful accusations.

This episode focuses on escaped serial rapist/killer William Lewis targeting Benson, not on false accusations of innocent people. Lewis kills Dr. Janice Cole, rapes her daughter Lauren, and kidnaps 12-year-old Amelia. He forces Benson to make a televised false confession admitting she committed perjury at his trial and used excessive force while he was handcuffed. The confession is coerced under duress (threat to Amelia's life), not an accusation against an innocent person. Episode ends with Benson shooting Lewis during Russian roulette standoff. No innocent people are falsely accused of sex crimes in this episode.

This episode is a police procedural focusing on Internal Affairs and grand jury investigation of Sergeant Benson after William Lewis's death. While Benson is accused of potentially killing Lewis (or using excessive force in a prior incident), she is the protagonist/detective being investigated, not a civilian wrongly accused of a sex crime. There are no external false suspects who meet the criteria - no civilians accused of sexual offenses who are later cleared. The episode is about institutional accountability of law enforcement, not wrongful accusation of the public.

Frank Maddox, Emmy-winning TV producer, accused by 8-year-old daughter Chelsea of sexual abuse in laundry room. Mother Catherine (estranged wife) brings claim amid bitter divorce after Frank's affair with her younger sister Rose. Case heavily contested: defense claims Catherine coaching/revenge; prosecution presents Chelsea's testimony, forensics. Middle sister Mavis reveals Frank raped her at age 13. Frank convicted but flees to France before cross-examination. Ambiguous whether Frank is guilty or Chelsea was coached—transcript supports both interpretations. Maddox exposed publicly via media circus, court proceedings, international press. Mavis (proven victim at 13) exposed when she testifies about her own rape.

Episode explores the boundaries of prosecuting someone for thoughts/fantasies vs. actions. Simon Wilkes, a photographer, is arrested for attempting to procure a child based on online chat activity and a 'torture chamber' he built. His case revolves around whether fantasies and preparation constitute criminal intent when no actual victim exists. The episode also features Gordon Montlieff ('Flash'), an initial suspect who cooperates with police. Wilkes is acquitted at trial. The episode raises civil liberties questions about prosecuting 'thought crimes' versus protecting potential victims.

Detective Nick Amaro is arrested and charged with assault after beating Simon Wilkes, a man recently acquitted of child sexual abuse charges, who was photographing children at a playground. Amaro is publicly arrested, charged with felony assault, held on $500,000 bail, and faces termination. The charges are later dropped when Wilkes admits he attacked Amaro first, but Amaro still faces administrative consequences. Separately, Hans Erhard, a German tourist, is robbed and raped in a hotel-room scam. He misidentifies pimp 'Little Tino' as his rapist in a lineup, but Tino is not charged with rape due to the misidentification. The episode ends with Benson becoming foster mother to baby Noah after his birth mother Ellie is murdered.

This episode focuses on dismantling a sex trafficking operation that previously killed Ellie Porter (Noah's mother). While several witnesses are threatened/killed, and there is police misconduct in the form of UC work that creates dangerous situations, there are no innocent persons falsely accused of sex crimes. The suspects identified (Little Tino, Joaquin, Angel/Teodoro, Selena) are all actually guilty of trafficking/pimping. The episode centers on protecting trafficked victims (Luna, Carmen, Missy) and prosecuting the actual perpetrators. Detective Amaro goes undercover as a corrupt cop but this is sanctioned police work, not a false accusation scenario. No person meets the criteria of being accused of a sex crime then proven/implied innocent with resulting public harm.

Retired basketball star Shakir Wilkins is accused of drugging and raping three women. Investigation reveals that Orion Bauer, CEO of Orion Bay (Shakir's sponsor), orchestrated false accusations by paying women to lie about being raped. Bauer's motive: Shakir had impregnated Bauer's daughter Cordelia, and Bauer wanted to destroy Shakir and void his contract. All charges are dismissed when the frame-up is exposed. Shakir is innocent but suffers massive reputation damage, loss of contract, and public humiliation.

Detective Nick Amaro is falsely accused by Tensley Evans of sexual extortion during a DUI arrest. The accusation is made publicly in court, creating professional risk. Dash cam footage proves him innocent, and the accusation is dismissed. The episode primarily focuses on Tensley's victimization by producer Adam Brubeck and her subsequent harmful behaviors.

Holden March, a 23-year-old with social difficulties, goes on a rampage attacking women who rejected him in the past (from grade school through his adult life). He stabs three women (all survive), murders his neighbors, and takes hostages at a school before being killed by police snipers. All victims correctly identified Holden as their attacker. There are no false suspects or wrongfully accused persons in this episode. Holden is the perpetrator throughout, and no innocent person suffers consequences from a mistaken accusation.

Evie Barnes, an 18-year-old college freshman who did pornographic videos to pay tuition, is raped by two students (Daniel Pryor and Matthew Cooper) who filmed the assault. Matthew confesses and testifies against Daniel, who is convicted by a jury. However, the judge overturns the verdict, citing Evie's pornography work as making it impossible to determine if her 'no' truly meant 'no.' Hudson University expels Evie for violating code of conduct (appearing in porn), not the rapists. No one is wrongly accused in this episode—the perpetrators are identified correctly from the start. Evie is the victim throughout, facing slut-shaming, victim-blaming, expulsion, and judicial bias, but she is never accused of anything criminal herself (only expelled for a university conduct violation). Daniel Pryor is accused and initially convicted, but the judge's reversal is based on evidentiary reasoning (however flawed), not on Daniel being proven innocent. The episode focuses on institutional failures and systemic victim-blaming rather than false accusations.

Charlie Dorsey, a homeless mentally ill man living in Inwood Hill Park, was arrested and publicly accused of stabbing 10-year-old Zoe Harris and kidnapping two other girls (Perry Gilbert, 13, and Mia Harris, 12). He was arrested in front of officers, tasered, forcibly restrained, and interrogated. Later evidence proved he was innocent—he actually saved Zoe. Perry Gilbert was revealed to be the perpetrator who stabbed Zoe and self-harmed, operating under delusions about 'Glasgowman.' Charlie was cleared but violated parole and sent to psychiatric program. Perry adjudicated delinquent, sent to Creedmore. Mia found not responsible.

SVU and Chicago PD investigate a decade-old child sex trafficking ring (Chess & Checkers Club) after Detective Lindsay's half-brother Teddy is identified as a victim in old photos. The investigation leads to George, a youth center security guard who recruits runaways, and Bob Clinton, who streams live abuse. While several people are arrested for solicitation or past crimes, no one is wrongfully accused of the sex trafficking crimes under investigation. Teddy and Jocelyn are victims who were forced to perpetrate abuse on other children, but the transcript does not show them being publicly accused or exposed as perpetrators - they are treated as victims throughout. George is guilty of recruiting children and Bob Clinton is guilty of trafficking. No false suspects with public exposure or material harm are identified in this episode.

A.J. Martin, a former NFL player and sports broadcaster, is prosecuted for reckless endangerment after video surfaces of him punching his partner Paula Bryant in a parking garage stairwell. Paula consistently defends A.J., insists she provoked him, and testifies on his behalf. The case proceeds despite her lack of cooperation. A.J. is convicted and remanded. This is a domestic violence prosecution case with a cooperative defendant and uncooperative victim. No false accusations or wrongly accused innocent persons appear in this episode.

SVU investigates a pattern rapist who has been active across Atlanta, Milwaukee, Vegas, and New York. Dr. Joseph Conklin is arrested when a victim's headphones are found in his car, but he is quickly cleared by blood type testing. The actual perpetrator is Albert Beck, an EMT who had access to Conklin's car keys. Beck confesses to 31 rapes. Dr. Conklin is exposed as a pill-pusher who traded sex for prescriptions but is innocent of the rapes.

This episode focuses on SVU investigating a rape allegation made by Atlanta detective Reese Taymor against her superior, Deputy Chief Patton. Detective Rollins discloses she was also raped by Patton years earlier under coercive circumstances. Both women are actual victims, not false suspects. Patton is the perpetrator who ultimately pleads guilty. There are no falsely accused innocent persons in this episode - the central conflict involves overcoming barriers to prosecuting a powerful officer. Episode does not meet inclusion criteria as it contains no innocent persons harmed by false accusations.

Madison Baker, 15, is found unconscious in a suitcase. She initially accuses a cab driver, then actor Scott Russo of rape. Russo is publicly arrested based on his manager Lydia Lebasi's false testimony framing him. Eventually, co-star Skye Adderson confesses to the actual sexual assault, and Lydia admits she framed Russo to protect her more lucrative client Skye. Russo is exonerated in court. The episode features false accusations, wrongful arrest, perp walk, media coverage, and career damage—all orchestrated by a Hollywood manager protecting a rising star.

Nicolas Amaro (Nick's father) is accused of assaulting his fiancée Gabriella at their rehearsal dinner. Gabriella initially tells Nick that Nicolas hit her, then recants and claims another guest (Javier Arenas) assaulted her and Nicolas was defending her. Javier is briefly investigated as a suspect but denies going downstairs. Nicolas is arrested, tried, and acquitted. The episode explores whether Gabriella's initial outcry or her recanted story is true, with strong implications that Nicolas is guilty but the case falls apart due to lack of witnesses and Gabriella's changed testimony.

16-year-old Jenna Davis is raped by her uncle Dr. Neil Alexander while sedated at his dental office. Drugged and confused, she misidentifies Jerome Jones (one of the 'Prospect Park Three' with a $36M lawsuit pending against NYPD) as her attacker. SVU arrests Jerome, then releases him due to lawsuit concerns. Jenna's father Luke kidnaps Jerome, tortures him with a nail gun to extract a coerced confession, and Jerome dies of an asthma-triggered heart attack. Jerome was completely innocent. Luke is arrested for felony murder. Jenna eventually remembers her uncle Neil raped her. Neil is arrested after Jenna wears a wire and gets him to admit the assault.

Raina Punjabi, a female game developer, is harassed online and then kidnapped and sexually assaulted by three male gamers (Anthony Rossi, Brandon, and Pierce) who oppose women in gaming. Her employee Sarah Keller is also assaulted at a gaming convention. The perpetrators are caught and are guilty of their crimes. No innocent persons are falsely accused or publicly exposed in this episode.

Martha Thornhill is arrested during an SVU sting on a sex trafficking operation. She claims to be undercover searching for her kidnapped daughter Ariel, who was taken 3 years ago in Toronto. Toronto police initially suspected Martha and her boyfriend, interrogating them for 3 days while the trail went cold. The boyfriend was a pot dealer who later died of overdose. Martha spent 3 years tracking Ariel through trafficking networks, posing as a madam to get close to the girls. SVU eventually helps her locate and rescue Ariel from trafficker Johnny D. The episode also reveals Declan Murphy is deep undercover in the trafficking ring. No innocent person suffers public exposure or material harm from false accusations in this episode—Martha is genuinely involved in trafficking (though with the motive of finding her daughter), and all other suspects (Timmer, Johnny D, Tracy, Selena) are actually guilty of trafficking crimes.

SVU investigates allegations that Charmaine Briggs is sexually abusing her elderly, dementia-afflicted husband Walter Briggs (famous novelist) by secretly giving him ED pills and forcing sexual activity. His daughters claim she's raping him and won't let them visit. During investigation, Walter has a heart attack; Charmaine removes him from hospital against medical advice. He dies shortly after. She's charged with manslaughter, later pleads to reckless endangerment. NO FALSE ACCUSATIONS are present—the entire episode is about investigating Charmaine's alleged abuse of Walter. There are no innocent people falsely accused then cleared. The investigation targets Charmaine throughout, and while charges are reduced via plea deal, she is never shown to be innocent of wrongdoing.

Tommy Sullivan, a parolee, discloses that his parole officer Donna Marshall raped him at gunpoint after a urine test. SVU investigates and finds another parolee, Jordan Dolphy, who also reports being coerced into sex by Marshall under threat and in exchange for clean drug tests. Marshall plants oxycodone in Tommy's apartment to discredit him. At trial, Dolphy is flipped by the defense and recants, but Barba exposes his fresh needle marks and coercion by Marshall's supervisor. This episode involves actual perpetrators (Donna Marshall as rapist; Ralph Kessel as accessory) rather than falsely accused innocent people. No person qualifies for inclusion under the rubric as all accused parties are shown to be guilty or complicit.

Heather Manning accuses four Hudson University hockey players (Brian Mackey, Connor Howell, Lance Mosconi, Zach Franklin) of gang-rape. Story goes viral on 'America's Worst Crimes' TV show. Three are arrested and perp-walked before cameras. Case collapses when: (1) Zach Franklin proves he was playing soccer in West Virginia during the alleged assault, (2) Heather's story changes from 4 to 6 assailants, (3) key details cannot be corroborated, (4) DNA evidence only proves consensual sex claims. All charges dropped. Three defendants publicly exposed as rapists despite being innocent or case unprovable.

Episode centers on Trudy Malko, an anti-vaxxer mother who coordinated with Dr. Setrakian to falsify vaccination records for her son Gabriel and other children at Tribeca Academy. This leads to a measles outbreak affecting dozens including Sergeant Benson's son Noah. Malko is arrested and prosecuted for reckless endangerment, conspiracy, and falsifying business records. The rainbow party subplot involves consensual activity among teenagers with no false accusations. No one is wrongly accused of a sex crime in this episode.

Serial killer Greg Yates kidnaps and murders Nadia Decotis. During his trial, Yates falsely accuses Sergeant Hank Voight of raping Nadia and implies Dr. Will Halstead was the actual murderer. Both accusations are demonstrably false and made in open court to damage reputations and create reasonable doubt. Yates is convicted.

Derek Thompson spent 17 years in prison for raping his daughter Michelle based solely on her testimony at age 6. As an adult in recovery, Michelle recants, stating her mother Audrey (who had substance abuse issues) coached her to lie after a marital fight. Investigation reveals the lead detective Ted McCormack was having an affair with Audrey before the trial—they vacationed together in Key West during the pre-trial period. Neither McCormack nor Audrey disclosed their relationship. Derek maintained innocence for 17 years. Defense attorney at original trial received exculpatory letter from Michelle's teacher (stating Michelle said her mother made her lie) but never used it. Case granted federal habeas corpus and retrial. During retrial, Michelle testifies father is innocent, but under aggressive cross-examination by ADA O'Dwyer, she becomes confused and says 'I don't know.' Episode ends with verdict being read. Derek suffered severe consequences: 17 years imprisonment, sex offender registry, separation from children, and public stigma of being labeled a child rapist and incest perpetrator.

Eight-year-old Owen Farhidi is kidnapped from school by Javier Rojas, who demands $37,000 ransom. Initially, both parents (divorced couple Dana and Sam Farhidi) are investigated, along with nanny Fabiana and her boyfriend Javier. Javier first claims Dana orchestrated it, then shifts blame to Sam. Ultimately, Sam confesses he arranged the kidnapping to teach his son not to trust strangers and to wake Dana up to being a more attentive parent. Dana is cleared when she wears a wire and Sam confesses on tape. No qualifying innocent persons with public exposure.

This episode focuses on the trial of sex trafficker Johnny Drake (Johnny D), who is revealed to be the biological father of Olivia Benson's foster son Noah. The defense attempts to paint Benson's investigation as a vendetta motivated by her desire to adopt Noah. While Johnny D's lawyer tries to use this conflict to discredit the case, there are no innocent people falsely accused in this episode. The witnesses (trafficking victims) all testify truthfully about Johnny D's crimes. One witness (Pilar) recants under apparent threat but is not herself accused of a crime. The episode ends with a courtroom shooting where Johnny D is killed by Nick Amaro, and Benson's adoption of Noah is finalized. No one meets the criteria for inclusion in person_rows: Johnny D is guilty of the crimes charged, and no other individual is accused of a sex crime they didn't commit.

Unable to analyze episode due to missing transcript. Cannot determine if any persons were falsely accused with public exposure or harmful consequences. Episode requires complete transcript for proper analysis.

This episode centers on the prosecution of Dr. Carl Rudnick, the Deputy Chief ME, for multiple murders including Susie Frain, Rachel Groves, and Lena Grunwald. Rudnick jumps bail, is captured in Buffalo disguised as a woman, stands trial, and ultimately pleads guilty to two murders. The episode does not feature any innocent person falsely accused with consequential public exposure or harm. The accused (Rudnick) is actually guilty and convicted. Greg Yates appears as a convicted murderer whose fiancée (Susie Frain) was murdered by Rudnick; Yates himself was correctly convicted in prior episodes. No qualifying false accusation victims are present in this transcript.

Three teenage boys assault a transgender teen (Avery Parker) in a park. Darius McCrae pushes Avery off a bridge; Avery later dies from embolism. All three boys confess. Markus and Keon receive probation; Darius is tried as adult for manslaughter + hate crime and convicted. No falsely accused persons identified—all three admitted involvement and evidence supports guilt. Darius's confession appears voluntary (mother present, rights read). While the episode explores whether Darius acted from hate vs. adolescent insecurity, and whether adult prosecution is just, he is not shown to be innocent of the underlying acts.

SVU investigates after finding a neglected boy wandering alone and his sister Keisha locked in a cage, starving. Keisha dies from prolonged abuse by her mother Manuela Ozuna. Investigation reveals that Child Services caseworker Keith Musio falsified home visit reports for months, supervised by Jeanette Grayson and Deputy Commissioner Matt Sheridan. All three are charged with manslaughter. Keith takes a plea deal and testifies against his supervisors. Jeanette has a breakdown in court and pleads guilty. Matt serves a year. The episode deals with institutional failure and fraud, but does not involve false accusations of sex crimes against innocent people.

Three officers from the one-two precinct pursue and fatally shoot Terrence Reynolds, believing him to be an armed serial rapist. DNA evidence later proves Reynolds was innocent and the actual rapist remains at large. Reynolds was shot 35 times while reaching for his keys to enter his apartment building. The shooting was captured on cell phone video and became a high-profile case. A grand jury indicted two officers for manslaughter one and a third for reckless endangerment. Reynolds' death was extensively covered by media and sparked community protests.

Anton Krasnikov, an internationally-renowned flautist, is accused of raping violinist Alessandra Bay after being seen naked on hotel surveillance entering and leaving her room. He claims he was drugged by an escort (Kim Rollins) who robbed him. Despite evidence he was drugged and exploited, Anton is arrested, publicly perp-walked, charged with rape, and remanded without bail. His career and reputation are destroyed. The escort (Detective Rollins' sister) later offers to testify against him as part of her own plea deal, ensuring his conviction despite his innocence of the rape. The episode demonstrates how a drugged and robbed victim becomes a falsely accused rapist with catastrophic professional and legal consequences.

13-year-old Lane Baker faints at her Virtue Ball and is discovered to be pregnant. Initially, she names cameraman Pete Matthews. The squad also suspects her older brother Graham. Both are innocent. The actual perpetrator is Pastor Gregory Eldon, who also fathered Summer Baker's child (Tate) three years prior. Pete Matthews faces child pornography charges for filming teenage girls undressing but did not commit statutory rape. Graham Baker was sent to Ecuador under false accusations to protect the pastor.

15-year-old Lily Evans goes missing and is later found murdered. Initially, Diego (a fitness instructor she was sexting) is suspected, followed by Robby Marino (a roadie with prior sexual assault arrest). Both are cleared via DNA. The actual killer is Gary Ryan, identified through familial DNA matching via his deceased biological father Ray Marino. While Diego and Robby face interrogation, neither experiences significant public exposure or lasting consequence—Diego's arrest is work-related and brief; Robby's interrogation is contained to the precinct with only his lawyer brother aware. The episode focuses on the investigation rather than harm to the falsely accused.

Lewis Hodda confesses to murdering Hector Rodriguez (1999) and kidnapping Wyatt Morris, but later recants and goes to trial. The trial focuses on Hector's murder. Defense attorney Lisa Hassler accuses SVU of coercing Hodda's confession and frames auxiliary officer Stephen Lomatin as an alternative suspect. The trial ends in a mistrial with a hung jury. Multiple people experience public exposure and harm from accusations during the episode.

Phoebe Burnap, a teacher, is falsely accused of catfishing and kidnapping student Zach Foster. While she did rape two other students (Travis and Jordan), she did not kidnap Zach. Wrestling coach Donald Basinski used her photos (obtained from Jordan) to catfish Zach. Burnap is publicly arrested, interrogated, and exposed as a rapist before the real kidnapper is identified. She was innocent of the kidnapping/catfishing accusation but guilty of other crimes.

The main plot involves Lt. Benson taken hostage during a home invasion. The subplot involves detectives arresting a man for being a 'push-in rapist' who assaulted multiple victims. The suspect claims innocence and threatens to sue, stating 'You got the wrong guy. Again.' His lawyer reinforces this, asking 'Who planted' the gun found on him. The detectives dismiss his claims and cite prints, DNA, and victim IDs. However, the suspect's repeated claims of wrongful arrest ('Again'), the lawyer's pointed questions, and the suspect's threat to sue suggest a pattern of false arrests. The episode does not provide clear resolution on whether he's actually guilty or innocent - the SVU team treats him as guilty, but the scripting suggests ambiguity.

Chris Roberts, 18, is accused of raping 15-year-old classmate Abby Stewart in a school darkroom during a dance. The case involves a 'Cherry Pickers Club' where senior boys competed to have sex with virgins. Chris initially lied to police about sexual contact, then admitted to foreplay but denied rape. DNA evidence confirmed sexual contact. The case goes to trial with conflicting accounts: Abby says she told him to stop and slow down but he continued; Chris claims everything was consensual and he thought she was willing. The jury finds him not guilty of attempted rape and forcible touching but guilty of sexual misconduct in the first degree, requiring sex offender registry. Both families are devastated. While Chris faces consequences, he is NOT proven or strongly implied innocent - the jury convicted him of sexual misconduct. Therefore, no person rows are included as this does not meet the 'innocent person harmed by false accusation' criteria.

Libby Parker is drugged, sexually assaulted, and left in a courtyard overnight while dozens of neighbors witness but fail to call 911. Three teenage suspects from a youth shelter (Ronnie Ellis, Juan Flores, William Reeves) are arrested based on video evidence, witness testimony, and a nanny who called 911 before being assaulted and threatened by Ronnie. Defense argues consent and memory issues due to drugs. All three are convicted. No false suspects identified in this episode.

Serial killers Greg Yates and Carl Rudnick escape from Green Haven Correctional with help from a volunteer teacher, Bronwyn Wilkins. The episode follows their manhunt, resulting in multiple murders. No one is falsely accused of a sex crime in this episode - the focus is entirely on pursuing two confirmed guilty inmates who have escaped.

Episode involves two separate cases: (1) UC sting operation catches Teddy Hawkins (former boxing champ) attempting to sexually exploit an undercover officer posing as a 15-year-old; (2) While investigating Hawkins' contacts, SVU discovers Deputy Commissioner Hank Abraham possessing and distributing child pornography. Abraham is arrested, his family is devastated, he attempts suicide, and ultimately pleads guilty. No innocent persons are falsely accused in this episode - both Teddy Hawkins and Hank Abraham are guilty of the crimes for which they are accused and both plead guilty.

Kristi Cryer accuses bar manager Noel Panko and celebrity Bobby D'Amico of rape at Bobby D's nightclub. The case involves conflicting victim testimony and issues with evidence collection. A second victim (Tara Browne) comes forward with similar allegations but won't testify. Detective Rollins goes undercover and captures video of D'Amico and Panko attempting to assault her in similar fashion, but this evidence is excluded from trial. Both defendants are acquitted. The excluded video later leaks to media. This episode contains NO innocent suspects - the accused men were acquitted by jury but the show strongly implies they are guilty through pattern evidence and the undercover operation. No person qualifies for inclusion in person_rows.

SVU raids a sex party attended by politicians and judges, discovering underage girls being trafficked. Vice detectives claim to be undercover. Sister Nina, a nun infiltrating the ring, identifies Vice cops Russo and Jefferson as rapists. Victim Cara Gutierrez dies of suspected hot shot overdose after agreeing to cooperate. Investigation reveals deep corruption possibly involving priests and IAB Captain Tucker, who is accused by Monsignor of burying prior evidence. Lieutenant Benson is removed from command amid the controversy.

IAB Captain Ed Tucker is falsely accused of running a sex trafficking ring by corrupt Vice detectives (Russo/Jefferson) at the direction of Monsignor Mulregan. Tucker is publicly exposed, investigated by Group One, transferred, and eventually forced into early retirement despite being innocent. The real traffickers are church officials who used this elaborate frame-up to protect themselves.

Attorney Thomas Zimmerman commits serial rapes near sex offender shelters to frame his clients. When therapist Robin Daughtry is raped/murdered, Zimmerman plants evidence in client Richie Caskey's apartment. Caskey is arrested in front of his wife and publicly accused before police realize Zimmerman is the true perpetrator. Gerald Loomis is also arrested for separate serial rapes (actually guilty).

17-year-old model Sally Landry accuses fashion photographer Alvin Gilbert of rape during a photo shoot. His assistant Nora Wattan facilitated and photographed the assault. Sally initially hesitates to press charges due to fear of her abusive boyfriend/manager Matt Kroger. The Gilberts attempt witness tampering by paying Matt $50,000. Nora eventually cooperates and provides videos of multiple rapes. Before trial, Alvin is murdered by his brother Benno, who had been cleaning up Alvin's messes for years. The case involves actual guilt (Alvin) and attempted witness tampering, but no innocent persons falsely accused with public exposure or material harm.

Melanie, a virgin contestant on reality dating show, is raped while unconscious in the Dream Suite. Producers initially edit footage to suggest Ryan was responsible, broadcasting this to 10 million viewers. Ryan is publicly accused on live TV before evidence shows Graham Turco was the actual rapist. Ryan suffers public accusation despite innocence. Producers manipulated footage and narrative throughout.

SVU investigates corrections officer Gary Munson for serial sexual assault of female inmates at Rikers and parolees on the street. Charisse McCabe, a former inmate, reports Munson raped her after release. Investigation reveals pattern of coerced sex with multiple inmates/parolees, enabled by fellow CO Orita as lookout. Munson arrested after attempting to rape Charisse while she wore a wire. Additional victim Leanne Carter (sister of inmate Della) testifies to being coerced into sex. Grand jury returns indictment on multiple rape/sodomy counts. No false accusations identified - Munson is shown to be guilty throughout. Episode focuses on institutional corruption enabling abuse, victim credibility challenges due to criminal records, and CO union retaliation.

Gary Munson, a corrections officer already indicted on multiple rape charges, takes his wife Lisa and Sergeant Dodds hostage during a domestic dispute when his wife attempts to leave him. The episode focuses on the hostage situation and its tragic outcome when Munson's gun accidentally discharges, fatally wounding Sergeant Dodds. This is primarily a hostage crisis/domestic violence episode, not a false accusation case. There are no wrongly accused individuals—Munson is facing legitimate rape charges from his position as a CO at Rikers, and the women he assaulted were inmates. The episode deals with the consequences of those charges on his family and the tragic outcome of the intervention.

SVU investigates Ana Kapic after she participates in a mass shooting in Central Park that kills an off-duty NYPD officer and wounds four others. The episode reveals Ana was repeatedly raped and tortured by her fiancé Luka Terzik and his brother Armin over five years. The case becomes intertwined with terrorism charges and a custody battle over Ana's son. While Ana is initially treated as a terrorist suspect, SVU Lieutenant Benson investigates and validates her rape allegations. Ana ultimately pleads guilty to murder one in exchange for protection of her son from Armin. The FBI takes Armin into custody on separate terrorism-related matters. No innocent persons are falsely accused in this episode - Ana is genuinely present at and complicit in the shooting, though her participation was under extreme duress from years of sexual violence and coercion.

Sean Roberts was wrongfully convicted of rape 16 years ago based on mistaken eyewitness identification by Melanie Harper. He served 16 years in prison where he was repeatedly raped. After being exonerated through rape kit testing, Sean is publicly celebrated at a press conference with the Vice President. One month after release, Ashley Harper (Melanie's daughter) is murdered. Multiple suspects emerge: Sean (ultimately guilty and confesses), Zach (Ashley's fiancé, cleared), and Charlie Dobkins (voyeur neighbor, cleared). The episode demonstrates severe consequences of the original wrongful conviction including 16 years imprisonment and repeated sexual assault in prison.

Tom Metcalf impersonates Alden Kessler to seduce mothers seeking college admissions advantages. The real Alden Kessler is questioned by SVU detectives at his workplace about rape allegations, creating public exposure and professional consequences. He is quickly cleared when detectives realize someone is using his identity. The episode focuses on whether Metcalf's fraud constitutes rape, with Laura Collett as the main victim who eventually testifies.

Olympic pole vaulter Jenna Miller reports being raped by Michael Wheeler after a paid sexual encounter. Wheeler admits to paid sex but denies rape. The investigation reveals Jenna has been working as an escort. During trial, Jenna's behavior leads to discovery she has undiagnosed bipolar disorder. Wheeler ultimately pleads to Assault Two. No innocent person is wrongly accused in this episode - Wheeler committed the assault he's charged with, and Jenna is the victim, not an accuser of an innocent person. The episode explores Jenna's mental health diagnosis and her secret double life, but there is no false accusation storyline.

Ellis Griffin is accused of raping Janie Spears while she was unconscious after a Halloween party. Initially claiming consent, Ellis pleads not guilty. His father Patrick Griffin, a Nassau County PD officer and former partner to Lt. Benson, attempts witness tampering to save his son. Ellis ultimately pleads guilty in open court, acknowledging he raped Janie while she was passed out. He is sentenced to 24 months in prison. No false suspect or wrongfully accused person appears in this episode—the accused is actually guilty and eventually confesses.

Eva Carson, a transgender art student, is brutally assaulted in a public bathroom and later dies. Investigation focuses on various suspects including boyfriend Logan, rapper Hype (Randall Leonard), producer Cash Lewis, and music executive Vincent Love. Logan is briefly suspected but quickly cleared via alibi. Hype initially lies about relationship with Eva but is cleared of the assault via video alibi. Cash Lewis is ultimately revealed as the likely perpetrator (killed by Hype in revenge). No innocent persons suffer public exposure or consequences from false accusations - Logan's brief questioning was private and he was quickly cleared via verifiable alibi.

Quinn Berris is sexually assaulted by a masked attacker. She suspects Ray Wilson, a man who stalked her in college and served time for breaking into her dorm closet. Ray is questioned by SVU at his workplace, a restaurant kitchen in front of colleagues. His DNA (a cigarette butt) is found at the crime scene, further implicating him. He is later fired from his job. It's eventually discovered that retired Sergeant Tom Cole—Quinn's trusted friend and protector—planted the evidence and is the actual rapist. Ray Wilson qualifies as a falsely accused person who suffered public exposure and job loss as a direct consequence of the wrongful accusation.

Six-year-old Theo Lachere goes missing after his mother Nadine throws a party. Investigation initially focuses on Gabriel Norton (violent ex-boyfriend) and Dr. Fran Conway (non-custodial parent attempting to gain custody). Both are publicly interrogated and suspected. Eventually revealed that nanny Gloria Ramirez orchestrated the kidnapping with her brother Oscar because she believed Theo would be neglected if taken to Ibiza. Gabriel was held on weapons charges despite no connection to the kidnapping. Fran was investigated as potential kidnapper despite being innocent.

Sarah Morrissey reports being raped at billionaire Lawrence Hendricks' birthday party. Eric Hendricks (Lawrence's grandson) is initially suspected after DNA match, but is later proven innocent - he had consensual sex with Sarah. Lawrence drugged and raped Sarah after Eric fell asleep. Eric is questioned at work (Avalon offices) in front of family members including aunt Cynthia and grandfather Lawrence. His father Larry also confronts detectives during interrogation. Eric faces workplace consequences as family members learn of accusation, though he is ultimately cleared when the real perpetrator (his grandfather) is exposed.

Dr. Nicole Keller falsely accused her son's friend Trey Franklin (15) of rape after her son Luke walked in on them having sex. Nicole cried 'Help! He's raping me!' causing Luke to shoot and kill Trey. Nicole maintained the rape claim through initial police interviews and trial testimony before changing her story. The false accusation was strategically deployed to cover up statutory rape and manipulate her son. Trey Franklin died as a direct result of the false accusation. Nicole was ultimately convicted of second-degree murder and statutory rape.

13-year-old Kyle Turner sexually assaults his teammate Jack Wilson with a hockey stick following orders from his abusive father Jim Turner. Jack later dies from infection. Kyle is coerced by his father and initially lies about the assault, then confesses. The detectives discover Jim physically abuses Kyle. Kyle eventually testifies against his father. No falsely accused persons qualify for inclusion—Kyle is guilty, and the case involves investigative tactics to get Kyle to admit his father's coercion. Jim Turner is arrested for child abuse based on video evidence and Adam's beating, not false accusation.

Captain Beth Williams is raped by her fiancé Mickey Reid. Unable to cope with the trauma and confused about memory, she falsely identifies Gary Cook, a misogynist online troll who was at the fight club that night. Cook is brought in for questioning and publicly accused despite having an ironclad alibi with witnesses placing him 50 blocks away visiting his grandmother. Beth later admits the mistake and identifies the real perpetrator as Mickey.

Jessica Walcott is raped outside a bar. Initially, Rodney Marsh is suspected due to his persistent harassment at the bar that night, but DNA clears him. The actual perpetrator, Nick Brown, confesses immediately upon arrest. The episode focuses on a therapy group for men who believe they have a genetic predisposition to rape. Sam Dalton, the 'River Rapist,' is identified through this group. Rodney is publicly questioned and swabbed at his workplace in front of colleagues before being cleared.

Zoe White accuses billionaire Eli Colton of rape after a work party. Investigation reveals Eli raped another banker, Kate Tompkins, three years earlier and paid her off. Roger Littrell, Zoe's supervisor at Cromwell Moore investment bank, attempts to cover up the crime by sending a fake email from Zoe's computer. Eli attempts to bribe Zoe through a $20M job offer at Sullivan Davis to prevent her testimony, but she refuses and testifies. No innocent persons were falsely accused in this episode - Eli Colton is guilty and convicted. Roger Littrell facilitated the cover-up but was not falsely accused of the sexual assault itself.

Jennifer Knowles is murdered and initially attributed to a serial killer (the Second Avenue Strangler). SVU discovers her actual killer was her boyfriend David Willard, a data-mining tech CEO who blackmailed witnesses and experts to cover his tracks. Two people are falsely accused with public exposure: Dr. Colin Bennett (rope expert blackmailed into falsifying evidence) and ADA Rafael Barba (blackmailed into recusing himself). The serial rapist/killer confessed to Jennifer's murder despite not committing it.

Episode focuses on multiple women accusing Harold Coyle, head of HNT network, of sexual assault and harassment. Heidi Sorenson, the primary victim, accuses Coyle of rape. Amy James (deceased, prior victim) and multiple other women come forward with harassment allegations. Margery Evans initially defends Coyle but later reveals he assaulted her as well. Coyle is convicted. No false suspects or wrongly accused individuals are identified in this episode - all accusations are directed at Coyle, who is ultimately shown to be guilty through Margery's recording and testimony.

Congressman Luke Bolton is falsely accused of involvement in a child sex trafficking ring through hacked emails and planted child pornography. The false accusations originate from a fake news website ('The Endless Truth') and lead to public exposure, threats, and ultimately violence. The investigation reveals Bolton was framed by hackers, but the fake news leads to discovery of an actual (unrelated) sex trafficking ring. Restaurant owner Mr. Lee is also falsely implicated and suffers business consequences and threats from believers of the conspiracy theory.

Declan Trask, who runs spiritual/Ayahuasca retreats, is accused of rape by Abby Clarke. She claims he hypnotized her into a dissociative state and then assaulted her. The case centers on whether hypnosis can render someone incapable of consent. Trask is convicted of rape in the first degree. No falsely accused innocent persons are identified in this episode - the defendant is found guilty and the evidence supports the victim's account. A deceased prior victim (Rachel Sykes) is mentioned but her case was never criminally prosecuted.

Ann Davenport, an 18-year-old from Indiana visiting NYC with her church group, is raped by Lucas Hull, a fellow congregant who believed he was 'curing' her homosexuality through 'curative intercourse.' Lucas confesses immediately, claiming religious justification. The episode explores whether this constitutes rape when the perpetrator and initially the victim both believe the act was religiously sanctioned. Reverend Gary Langham is revealed to have orchestrated a pattern of such assaults, paying young men including Lucas to perform 'curative intercourse.' Lucas himself had been subjected to conversion efforts after Gary caught him with another boy. Both Lucas and Gary ultimately plead guilty. No falsely accused persons are identified in this episode—the perpetrators are known and confess from early in the investigation.

Three masked men raid the Samra family's Muslim restaurant, resulting in two rapes, two murders. Hector Ramirez, a fired employee, is identified by witness Yusef Massad as being present. Hector is arrested and arraigned but maintains innocence, claiming he was home with his wife. Critical witness Yusef is deported by ICE before he can testify before the grand jury. Without Yusef's testimony, prosecutors release Hector due to insufficient evidence (only hair strands found at scene where he previously worked). Hector appears to be innocent or at minimum a non-participant observer, wrongly accused based on a witness ID that becomes unavailable.

Hector Ramirez was an accomplice (not innocent) who cooperated and was murdered. His wife Soledad was threatened with ICE deportation and child removal to force testimony. Mitchell Jenkins' wife Carleen was similarly threatened (perjury/child loss) to flip on her husband. Episode depicts coercive tactics against immigrant witnesses/families but does not feature falsely accused individuals who are later proven innocent. All accused parties (Hector, Mitch, Stevie) were actually guilty of the crimes.

Detective Fin Tutuola tracks down serial rapist Byron Marks in Cuba and brings him back to face charges. The case involves legal complications regarding the arrest and Cuba's attempt to reclaim Marks. Three rape victims are reluctant to testify due to trauma and stigma. Marks' Cuban wife initially testifies on his behalf but ultimately changes her testimony after learning the truth about his crimes. There is a subplot where Noah tells his school nurse that his mother (Olivia Benson) gave him a bruise, which is later clarified as having occurred when she grabbed him to prevent him from being hit by a taxi. The school questions Benson but the matter is resolved as a misunderstanding with no formal investigation or consequences. At episode's end, a new investigator reveals he's investigating Benson for child abuse, setting up the season arc.

Savannah Ross reports being raped by a masked attacker calling himself 'Prince Charming.' Due to her history of previous discredited rape claims in foster care and inconsistencies in her account, detectives initially doubt her credibility. Lieutenant Benson eventually believes her, and the investigation uncovers additional victims (Nancy Burns, Anne Speer, Vivian Stevens). Tom Williams is identified as the serial rapist and dies by suicide during apprehension. No innocent person is wrongly accused or publicly harmed in this episode.

Jason Karr is castrated by Evelyn Bundy, a former student he had sexual relationships with when she was 16. Investigation reveals Karr had relationships with multiple students 20 years ago. Evelyn claims he also forcibly raped her using a corkscrew as a weapon. Despite the mutilation Karr suffered, he is prosecuted and convicted of rape. No falsely accused innocent persons are identified in this episode - Karr is the victim of assault but is himself guilty of statutory rape and forcible rape. The three women (Evelyn, Julie, Nora) initially lie to police but are victims, not false accusers.

15-year-old Mandy Fowler reports being raped at a party. Three boys are initially arrested: Daniel Ross and Max Rivera for taking indecent photos/drawing on her unconscious body, and Andrew Drake for rape. Daniel and Max are cleared of rape charges and testify against Andrew. Andrew ultimately pleads guilty and allocutes in court, confirming he raped Mandy. Daniel and Max were publicly arrested at school for acts they committed (creating and distributing images) but were innocent of the rape itself.

A young woman claiming to be Emma Lawrence, kidnapped 10 years earlier, is revealed to be Britney Taylor, a 21-year-old con artist with an abusive background. Investigation uncovers that Glenn Lawrence accidentally killed his sister Emma at age 8 and his father Bill covered it up. Bill and Glenn accept plea deals. No innocent persons were falsely accused then cleared - Glenn confessed to manslaughter, and Bill to covering up the crime. The case involves deception by Britney Taylor but no wrongful accusations of innocent parties. The B-plot involves Olivia Benson navigating custody/visitation issues with Noah's grandmother Sheila Porter, which is family court matter not related to false accusations.

15-year-old Natalie Curtis overdoses and dies after escaping from Lux Rehab. Investigation reveals Dr. Barkley and counselor Anthony Parker were running a scheme: Barkley overbilled insurance at Lux, sent girls to Altbrook sober house where Anthony traded drugs for sex, girls relapsed and returned to Lux for more billing cycles. Natalie was raped by Anthony and impregnated while at Altbrook. No false accusations occur in this episode - the investigation correctly identifies the perpetrators. Episode ends with social worker Rosemary Taylor murdering Dr. Barkley with fentanyl as revenge.

Laurel Linwood reports being raped after being found at a museum. Investigation reveals she met Greg Harvey at a bar and went to his apartment, where she killed him with scissors. Through interrogation, it emerges Laurel fabricated memories of childhood sexual abuse by her father - the actual victim was her sister Leah.
