Laurel's false memories and killing of Harvey stemmed from jealousy that her father never abused her like he did Leah. Greg Harvey was innocent of rape; Laurel killed him in a displaced rage at her father. The accusation against Harvey (posthumously) and the childhood sexual abuse dynamics are central, but Harvey's innocence only becomes clear through Benson's interrogation revealing Laurel's fabricated narrative.

MMA fighter Andy McPherson is accused of raping Instagram influencer Katy Miller. Investigation reveals both were catfished by Heather Parcell, who impersonated each to the other via fake texts and accounts. Andy believed Katy had a rape fantasy; Katy believed Andy was interested in a normal relationship. Andy takes a plea deal (Rape 3, probation) to enable prosecution of Heather. No evidence Andy faced public exposure beyond initial police contact. Heather is convicted as an accomplice to rape.

Noah Benson is kidnapped from a mall by his biological grandmother Sheila Porter and accomplice Juan Ortoli. Initial investigation focuses on a man with mutton chops (brown bomber jacket) at Starbucks who spoke to Noah, but he is cleared - he was trying on pants in a dressing room for over an hour during the kidnapping window. Juan Ortoli, Sheila's gardener/romantic interest, is the actual kidnapper seen on security footage. Both innocent suspects were investigated but never publicly exposed or materially harmed. This episode tracks the SVU squad's race to recover Noah, not false accusation consequences.

Episode centers on Mariel McLaughlin (15, wheelchair-bound) and Cody Hill (19, autistic) found in a sexual encounter at school. Initial investigation reveals Mariel's mother Dawn has Munchausen by Proxy, systematically medicating and sickening Mariel for 15 years. Cody is initially accused of rape but cleared when both teens say it was consensual. The main false accusation involves Cody; Mariel later kills her mother. Episode includes extensive public exposure of Cody at school and questioning in front of family.

This episode centers on Tara Sidnana, a co-pilot who forces a plane to return to JFK after being paired with Captain Logan Carter, who had raped her 6 months earlier. Optimum Air had known about the rape but silenced her with promises of promotion. SVU investigates, finds corroborating evidence including bruises, a controlled call confession, and a second victim (Jeanne Howell). Carter pleads guilty to two counts of rape. ADA Barba then convenes a grand jury indicting Optimum Air for institutional complicity in sexual harassment and assault. No innocent persons are falsely accused in this episode—the investigation vindicates the victims and results in the rapist's conviction.

Justin Vichinsky, an antifa protestor, is arrested for sexually assaulting Martha Cobb during a riot at Hudson University. His DNA is found under her fingernails from a physical altercation, and she identifies him in a lineup. However, defense counsel Jed Karey introduces Randy Platt, an alt-right extremist who Martha had publicly humiliated the night before, as an alternate suspect. Martha later admits uncertainty about her identification after the head trauma she suffered. The ADA dismisses the case, citing inability to prove guilt beyond reasonable doubt. Vichinsky is publicly arrested, charged, tried, and subjected to public vilification before being cleared.

Aaron Householder kidnaps his dying infant son Drew to prevent court-ordered euthanasia. ADA Barba later performs mercy killing, faces murder trial, is acquitted, but resigns. Episode deals with end-of-life ethics, NOT false sexual assault accusations. No person qualifies for tracking under this study's criteria—the case involves familial kidnapping and euthanasia, not sex crimes or false accusations thereof.

Detective Brian Cassidy is falsely accused of murdering Dr. West after his courtroom outburst causes a mistrial. Cassidy went to West's house while intoxicated, was knocked unconscious, and woke up next to West's body covered in blood. He is publicly arrested and processed through Central Booking with a perp walk. The actual killer is revealed to be Reggie, a victim who was protecting his younger brother Sammy from further abuse. Cassidy is cleared when fish DNA on the murder weapon traces back to Reggie's fishing knife.

Ethan Hartley is accused of rape by Mia Marino (Carisi's niece). University tribunal suspends him for one year. NYPD investigates but DA declines to prosecute the first allegation due to insufficient evidence. Mia later admits the first accusation was false—she consented but lied because she regretted it and feared her roommate's judgment. Ethan is then accused of a second rape (真实 rape) when Mia invites him to apologize and he assaults her. Carisi testifies at trial that the first rape never occurred. Ethan is convicted of the second rape. The first false accusation caused severe public and material harm: Ethan was suspended from Hudson University, banned from campus, could not apply to other schools, lost his pre-med track, and faced widespread social ostracism ('scarlet R').

A 12-year-old girl dies from a head injury during a prank. Initially, a man on a bike (David Gidumal) is suspected after being seen with the victim moments before she disappeared. He is arrested and his apartment forcibly entered. The case quickly pivots to the accidental death, but Gidumal suffered police intrusion and brief detention as an innocent suspect. The episode then focuses on Dr. Franchella, who harvested organs without parental consent and is convicted of forgery.

16-year-old Haley Sadler goes missing after a club outing in NYC. Vincent Drago, a butcher who was with her that night, is arrested and charged with her murder based on blood evidence in his apartment and car. He is publicly accused, arraigned in court, and subjected to intense interrogation. He maintains innocence throughout. Haley is later found alive—she staged her disappearance with her music teacher James Turner (her biological father, unknown to both). Drago was innocent of the murder charge but faced public trial, media exposure, arrest, and potential life sentence.

Episode follows investigation of prostitute Sandy 'Sky' Ksenivich's assault and rape. Three soldiers involved: Private Billy Shaughnessy (innocent, had consensual encounter), Sergeant Jim Preston (innocent, transgender man forced into room and hit with lamp while trying to help), and Staff Sergeant Tyler Jones (guilty perpetrator). Both innocent soldiers faced significant exposure and consequences stemming from false/mistaken accusations before the truth emerged. Jim Preston faced particularly severe exposure as his transgender status was forcibly revealed in court proceedings despite his gender identity being irrelevant to the crime.

Nick Hunter is arrested for murdering his wife Jules and daughter Ruby after Jules' car is found with blood and evidence of a struggle. However, it's revealed that Alex Cabot (former ADA) helped Jules fake her death and disappearance as part of an underground network protecting domestic violence victims. Jules was being abused by Nick but never reported it to authorities. When Olivia discovers Jules is alive, she convinces her to return and fight for custody in family court rather than remain in hiding. Jules testifies about the abuse but is killed in a hit-and-run before the custody hearing concludes. Nick ultimately gains custody of Ruby. While Nick is the actual abuser (not innocent), no one in this episode qualifies as a falsely accused innocent person who suffered public exposure or consequences from a mistaken accusation.

Episode centers on Esther Labott, a 27-year-old woman found on a train who had been abused and controlled by her father William Labott in a cult-like household. Investigation reveals incest, child abuse, starvation, and physical restraint of children. Father William and mother Debbie Labott are the actual perpetrators. No false accusations or wrongly accused innocent persons appear in this episode. The case ends tragically with a police siege where Esther and children are killed, with Detective Rollins firing the fatal shot that killed Esther.

Three teenage boys (Leonard, Darryl, DeShawn) are initially accused of gang rape but are later revealed to have paid for sex (solicitation, not consensual given victim's incapacitation). They are arrested, taken to precinct, and their grandmother notifies their lawyer. The actual perpetrator is Malik Williams, who trafficked his own 16-year-old sister Tiana. The boys are publicly exposed during arrest at playground, questioned at precinct with family/attorney present, and face rape accusations before charges are eventually dropped when prostitution arrangement is revealed.

Episode follows investigation of rapes of elderly women in care facilities. Leonard Maxwell is initially suspected when Madeline Thomas (dementia patient) names 'Max' as her rapist, but she conflated a consensual 1966 encounter with Maxwell with a recent rape by healthcare worker Henry Phillips. Maxwell was never publicly accused or exposed - investigation kept him police-only. Phillips used fake IDs to work as temp in multiple facilities, raping elderly patients. No qualifying innocent persons with public exposure.

Lourdes Vega holds Miguel Lopez hostage, accusing him of trafficking, torture, and rape from 5 years ago in Texas. Lopez claims he was in Portland during that time and denies all accusations. Police confirm Lopez was indeed in Portland in 2013. Another trafficking victim from the same safe house (Maria) does not recognize Lopez. Lourdes forces a 'confession' at gunpoint, but its validity is questionable. Episode ends ambiguously regarding Lopez's guilt. Jorge Diaz (apartment owner) dies from injuries. Case presents as possible mistaken identity, though Lourdes is adamant. No definitive proof Lopez is the actual trafficker.

Lourdes Vega, a trafficking victim working as a nanny, encounters Miguel Lopez at a club and believes he is the coyote who raped and tortured her 5 years prior. She kidnaps him at gunpoint, forces a confession, and accidentally kills Jorge Diaz. Miguel initially denies knowing Lourdes, claims mistaken identity, and another trafficking victim (Maria) does not recognize him. However, Miguel ultimately confesses to being a trafficker/rapist who transported girls. The episode leaves ambiguous whether Lourdes correctly identified Miguel or if he falsely confessed under duress. No clear public exposure of Miguel occurs - interrogations are private, and there's no indication of workplace/family/media exposure before his ultimate confession to detectives. The narrative treats Miguel as guilty by episode's end, though earlier scenes suggest possible mistaken identity.

Sam Conway, 15, is raped by his father John Conway during a hunting trip. Gus Haverford, a stranger who helped Sam when he was drunk, is briefly investigated as a suspect but quickly cleared. Brian Conway, Sam's older brother, is also briefly suspected before the investigation focuses on the father. John Conway is tried but acquitted despite strong evidence. Episode includes one falsely accused person (Gus Haverford) who faced detective questioning but was cleared relatively quickly.

Episode centers on Sam Conway, a 15-year-old who was sexually assaulted by his father John Conway. The father was tried and acquitted for the rape. Following the acquittal, Sam brings guns to school and shoots classmates, killing two and injuring five. The episode later prosecutes the father for criminally negligent homicide based on creating a toxic environment that led to the shooting. While John Conway was initially a suspect in the sexual assault case and acquitted by jury, he was NOT proven or strongly implied innocent - the jury verdict appears to be a miscarriage of justice rather than exoneration. Sam is demonstrably guilty of the school shooting. No qualifying false accusation victims are present in this episode.

SVU rescues trafficking victims including Gabriela, a 9-year-old separated from her mother at the border. Lieutenant Benson arrests federal immigration officer Jeff Phelps for kidnapping, charging him for separating Gabriela from her mother. The arrest is highly publicized via a press conference. A federal judge rules the arrest illegal under supremacy clause, releasing Phelps. Episode demonstrates consequences of politically-motivated arrest of an officer performing lawful federal duties.

Episode depicts three incels (Riley Porter, Chris Carnasis, Tony Kelly) who coordinate stranger rapes of women (Anne Whitman, Beth Palmer, Carol Solomon) as revenge for perceived slights against each other. Jake Sanders, a spin instructor with a gun who stalked Brianna, was initially suspected but had an alibi teaching a spin class during the first rape. No innocent persons were publicly accused, arrested, or harmed by false accusations. The perpetrators are eventually identified through online communications and confessions. Tony Kelly raped Carol Solomon based on a high school rejection that turned out to be a wrong phone number.

Vicky Parson is murdered. Her ex-boyfriend Brad Simon becomes the primary suspect after evidence (blood on his clothing) appears to link him to the crime. The SVU squad later discovers that the blood was planted by Gina Goodrich on orders from Arlo Beck, leader of Accredo (a women's empowerment group). Lilah Finch, Arlo's coordinator, confessed to the actual murder under Arlo's direction. Brad was publicly accused, had evidence planted against him, and faced arrest before being cleared when the real perpetrators were identified.

Sophie Simmons (using alias 'Grace Walker') reports being raped by Silas Perry after a night of drinking. SVU investigates Silas, who admits to sex but claims it was consensual prostitution and that Sophie attacked him with a steel rod, attempting robbery. Sophie later recants, admitting she accepted payment for sex and tried to steal more money from Silas. The real trauma: Sophie was raped by Professor Logan Adams during freshman year at Spence College, which triggered Dissociative Fugue Disorder, causing her to abandon her identity and live on the streets for three years as 'Grace.' Adams died before being held accountable. No innocent person suffered public exposure or material harm from false accusation in this episode—Silas was briefly investigated but never publicly accused or sanctioned.

When a family of four is found murdered in their home, detectives initially suspect and arrest the family's nanny, Dolores Alvarez, after she flees the scene with the murder weapon. Evidence later reveals that the mother, Anna Mill, committed the murders. Dolores is publicly accused, arrested, and held in Rikers before being cleared. The actual perpetrator, Anna Mill, is convicted of murdering her husband but acquitted of murdering her children by reason of insanity, then dies by suicide in custody.

Episode focuses on chef Andrew Liebowitz who sexually assaults employee Kayla Morgan and is later revealed to have assaulted multiple women. ADA Chris Hodges from Brooklyn is exposed as having covered up prior cases and as having himself attempted rape in high school alongside Liebowitz. No innocent persons are falsely accused - all accused parties (Liebowitz and Hodges) are shown to be guilty. The Uber driver Michael Boykin is briefly suspected but quickly cleared when evidence shows he was on phone with wife and Kayla confirms he didn't assault her. However, this does not meet criteria for inclusion as there was no public exposure beyond initial police contact and no material harm - he was questioned privately and immediately released.

Peter Stone is accused by Sarah Kent of raping her 12 years ago after a baseball game. Stone denies the accusation and asks SVU to investigate. The accusation leads to his arrest and public exposure. Sarah's husband Gary holds Stone at gunpoint in a bar confrontation. Investigation reveals that Stone's friend Reggie Griggs was actually the rapist; Stone had passed out. Charges against Stone are dropped and Griggs is arrested.

A book reading for underground author 'Bobbi O'Rourke' ends in murder when the stand-in reader (Tammy, a teen sex worker) is killed by William Glover, a client who felt deceived upon learning 'she' was male. SVU discovers the publisher orchestrated a fraud: the real author was Ben Edelman, a 73-year-old recluse who never left his house since 1973. Glover is arrested and confesses. Investigation into Ben and his brother Joe reveals both were childhood sexual abuse survivors. Joe dies of heart attack during trial for their mother's mercy killing.

Dr. Heath Barron and girlfriend Sadie Parker are accused of drugging and raping Ava Parcell after a party. Investigation reveals Sadie is actually Ceci Taylor, a teen runaway who disappeared 14 years earlier. Barron groomed, assaulted, and surgically transformed her. Before discovering Sadie's true identity, detectives interview Lee Black (Ava's dance partner) who is ruled out as suspect. The couple also defames Ava publicly on TV, calling her a liar seeking a payoff. Multiple previous sexual partners are contacted but all claim consensual encounters. Case ultimately reveals Barron murdered another victim (Moira) whose body was found in walls of his former residence.

Karl Patton confesses to being the Infinity Rapist and is arrested for raping April Baker. He's publicly identified in media interviews. Later revealed as copycat when real Infinity (Edgar Noone) strikes again. Patton was innocent of being the original Infinity but guilty of the Baker assault he confessed to.

Greg Callahan, a neighbor, groomed and sexually abused 13-year-old Laura Moore. He manipulated her into falsely accusing her father Douglas Moore of sexual abuse. Laura's older sister Britney, believing the false accusation, killed their father to protect Laura. Doug Moore was innocent of the sexual abuse accusation but died before being cleared. The episode reveals Greg orchestrated the false accusation to cover his own abuse and gain custody of the girls through forged guardianship documents.

Annabeth Pearl is on trial for murdering her husband Thomas, a police officer. The prosecution argues it was premeditated murder; the defense claims she was a victim of years of psychological abuse. SVU detectives Benson, Rollins, Carisi, and Tutuola testify at trial and struggle with their own moral judgments about whether Annabeth's actions were justified. The episode explores the power of police testimony and the complexities of domestic abuse, but does not involve a wrongly accused suspect in an SVU case. This is a courtroom drama centered on a murder defendant, not an innocent person harmed by a false sex crime accusation.

SVU investigates the death of Torie Meeks, a drug court participant who fell/jumped from a roof while trying to escape a pop-up brothel. Investigation reveals Judge Edward Kofax was running a sex trafficking ring, exploiting women from his own drug treatment court with help from dirty cops (Detective Ramirez, Officer Taggart) and a pimp (Carlos/Devon Jones). Kofax believed he was 'protecting' the addicted women like his deceased daughter Delia. No innocent persons are falsely accused in this episode—the investigation correctly identifies the guilty parties from the start. Client Collum O'Connor is briefly questioned after Torie's death but is released once his alibi (being tied up during the incident) checks out; however, there's no indication of public exposure or lasting harm to him.

Gary Dolan molested multiple boys over decades. Micah Fuller (victim, deceased by suicide) left photos and note naming Gary. Investigators confirmed Dolan's guilt through Leo Berry's testimony and Brian Cassidy's eventual testimony. No false accusations occurred. Two boys from Micah's bookstore reading group (Jason and Tommy) were investigated but quickly cleared when parents confirmed they were not in the photos. This was standard investigative elimination, not a false accusation with public exposure or harm.

Bailey Shaw is found in a car trunk after being kidnapped from Central Park. Investigation initially focuses on car thief Soren West and birth surrogate Paige Johnston before identifying 'Emerson Mauer' as kidnapper. Twist: 'Emerson' is actually Kevin Brown, kidnapped in 2002 at age 6 and raised by Rowan Mauer who killed her real son. Soren West and Paige Johnston were both falsely suspected and publicly exposed during investigation.

Attorney Nikki Staines is drugged and sexually assaulted after a police philanthropy event. She reports the crime to SVU. Investigation reveals Rob Miller, opposing counsel in her civil rights lawsuit against NYPD, had non-consensual sex with her while she was unconscious in his limo and stole her phone containing sensitive case information. Miller manipulated judges, intimidated the victim, and arranged for Benson to be pulled over by State Police as retaliation. Miller is ultimately arrested. No false suspects are accused or publicly exposed in this episode - the investigation correctly identifies Miller as the perpetrator from the start once his involvement is discovered.

Dr. Josh Hensley is accused of rape by Kitty Bennett, who disrupts his wedding ceremony. Initial investigation suggests fabrication due to Kitty's stalking history and inconsistent details. However, DNA proves Hensley is the father of Kitty's baby. Hensley admits to consensual affair but maintains innocence. Eventually, his fiancée Lana Stallworth reveals Hensley was her therapist who raped her, using the same psychological manipulation tactics he used on Kitty. Both women were therapist-patient or therapist-client relationships where Hensley exploited professional power, raped them, then convinced them the assault was consensual or their fault. Hensley is arrested on new charges for raping Lana. No false suspects identified - the accused is guilty.

Mackenzie Tolliver (13) falsely accuses her drama teacher Mr. Dreyfus of impregnating her to protect her stepfather/husband Garrett Howard, who is actually the father. Garrett kills Dreyfus based on this lie. Dreyfus is exposed publicly through the investigation and ultimately murdered before being cleared. The marriage to Garrett is later revealed to be legal under Missouri law (father bribed $10k for consent). Garrett eventually confesses to the murder and manipulation of Mackenzie.

Two Italian exchange students (sisters Emilia and Lara) were groomed and abused by their host father Richard Matthews. Matthews fabricated sexual abuse allegations against their biological father in Italy, coaching both girls to testify falsely. The father was imprisoned in Italy based on their coached testimony. The girls' mother was socially ostracized in their Italian town. The false accusation is revealed when Emilia's word-for-word repetition of her sister's testimony alerts detectives to coaching. The father is later exonerated and released from prison.

Dallas, wife of rapper Snake, is brutally assaulted in her home. Snake is initially suspected due to domestic dispute history and rage room videos showing him threatening Dallas. He is arrested but later cleared when Dallas's alibi confirms he was at the Apollo during the assault. Rapper RB Banks is also briefly suspected after making threatening statements but alibis out. The actual perpetrator is Andreas Harper, son of Malik Harper (a man Snake killed in self-defense 18 years prior), seeking revenge by attacking Snake's wife.

Councilwoman Nahla Nasar is raped in a synagogue. Two Jewish teenagers (Ari Kaplan and Michael Schwartz) are initially suspected after being seen fleeing the scene and having confronted Nasar earlier that day. The boys are publicly identified in media reports and interrogated by SVU. Investigation reveals Nasar orchestrated the earlier confrontation for political purposes and later identifies her ex-husband Masud Faraj as her actual rapist. The teenagers were innocent but suffered public exposure and interrogation as suspects in a politically charged case.

Rob Miller is accused and convicted of murdering 16-year-old Lindsay Parker after she could potentially identify him at an underage sex party. However, the conviction is obtained through manufactured evidence: ADA Peter Stone and attorney Nikki Staines frame Miller by planting $9,500 in witness Brooke Davis's bank account and falsely testifying about it. While Miller is genuinely guilty of multiple crimes (rape of Nikki Staines, witness intimidation, judicial blackmail), the specific murder conviction is secured through prosecutorial misconduct. Stone admits he fabricated evidence because 'the law's just not good enough' and to protect Olivia and her son from Miller's threats. Stone resigns afterward, acknowledging his ethical violations. This episode presents a moral dilemma: a dangerous criminal is convicted, but through illegal means. However, there are no innocent people harmed by false accusations in this episode - Miller is the only person accused, and while the specific evidence against him was manufactured, the show strongly implies his actual guilt in Lindsay's death and explicitly shows his guilt in other crimes.

episode_title: I'm Going To Make You a Star
summary: Sir Tobias Moore, a powerful media executive, is investigated and eventually arrested for multiple sexual assaults against aspiring actresses during auditions. The episode follows detectives working with victims Pilar Reyes and others, culminating in an undercover operation with Detective Kat Tamin that captures Moore on camera assaulting her. Moore is arrested and arraigned. There are no innocent persons falsely accused in this episode—the primary suspect is ultimately arrested and charged. The episode also depicts organizational politics affecting Chief Dodds, who is transferred after the case creates friction with the DA's office, but this is a career consequence unrelated to any accusation of wrongdoing.

Raegan is gang-raped by four men (rideshare driver Nick, passenger Julius, boat owner Anthony Marino, and Frank Corso) after a night out drinking. All four are eventually arrested and their DNA places them at the crime scene. There are no false suspects in this episode - all four men were actually involved in the assault (though Marino claims he left before participating). The detectives use trauma-informed interviewing to help Raegan recover her memories. The case results in plea deals rather than trial.

A serial predator (Jeffrey Moran) is attacking closeted gay Black men in Hell's Kitchen. Pop star Mathis Brooks fabricates his own assault to preempt being outed by TMZ, copying the MO. Mathis is proven to have staged his attack (brother bought taser, alibi proves Moran wasn't involved). Moran is arrested based on Mathis's false report but is actually guilty of assaulting three other victims. Mathis's false report poisons public trust but inadvertently leads to Moran's arrest and plea deal. No charges filed against Mathis despite public exposure of his fabrication.

Isaac Franklin (19) was initially suspected of impregnating 13-year-old Evangeline Miller due to his prior statutory rape case in Ohio and her coming to NYC to stay with him. Detectives questioned him about their relationship. However, he was never publicly accused or exposed beyond police questioning in his apartment. Evangeline eventually revealed her stepfather James Miller as the actual perpetrator (DNA-confirmed, 114 counts of rape). Isaac's involvement was limited to private police interrogation with no workplace, family, media, or community exposure documented in transcript.

Three cases involving sexual assault accusations. Mohammed Sayeed, a HailMe driver, is wrongfully arrested and held for 24 hours after victim Chloe Cooper misidentifies him; the actual assailant is Sanjay Patel. Paul Davies is accused of assaulting trans sex worker Lakira Baca, but she later recants (likely coerced). Leon Fuller is arrested for DV/rape of his wife Joelle, who backs away from charges due to financial dependence. Mohammed is the clearest case of wrongful accusation with public exposure.

Episode centers on a 2019 rape of Lupe Perez that links via DNA to a 2003 double murder in Far Rockaway. Carlos Hernandez (18 at time) and Ricardo Torres (15 at time) were coerced into confessing to murdering Carlos's mother Nydia and sister Jacinta. Both were innocent. Carlos served 16 years in prison; Ricardo served 15 and died of AIDS shortly after release. The actual perpetrator, maintenance worker Tim Stanton, evaded detection for 16 years. Both false confessions were products of coercive interrogation by Detective Monte, who explicitly threatened Carlos with execution and convinced Ricardo to turn state's evidence with false promises.

Episode involves a trafficking operation where workers are genuine victims, not falsely accused perpetrators. Charlie is arrested but portrayed as protecting/loving Lily (a victim). Rick Olin and Theo Pappas are accused of rape/assault and appear guilty (Theo pleads guilty, Rick negotiates). The Changs are arrested for trafficking and appear guilty (Christine confesses). No one is shown or implied to be innocent of what they're accused of. This is a straightforward trafficking/exploitation case without false accusations against innocent parties.

Three women (Meghan Gale, Jane Doe, and Freja Bergdahl) are drugged with massive doses of DMT and sexually assaulted by members of Dr. Julius Adler's 'radical therapy' institute. The episode centers on Adler's exploitation of vulnerable students under the guise of psychedelic therapy. While Adler is arrested, there are no individuals accused of sex crimes who are later proven innocent. The case involves actual perpetrators (Adler, his daughter Anais, pedicab driver Caleb, and other institute members) who are appropriately identified and charged. No false suspects or wrongful accusations occur in this episode.

Billionaire Steve Getz sexually exploits teenage models, including 15-year-old Ivy Bucci. Her father Frank Bucci (a retired detective) reports the abuse. Getz is arrested and charged with rape and forcible touching. He pleads guilty to a reduced charge (criminal sexual act), but the judge dismisses all serious charges at sentencing, releasing him with time served on a prostitution charge. No one is falsely accused or wrongly implicated in this episode. The case centers on a guilty perpetrator evading accountability through legal maneuvering. Frank Bucci's mental health deteriorates throughout, culminating in him holding Captain Benson at gunpoint in her therapist's office in the final scene.

Frank Bucci, father of victim Ivy, takes Detective Rollins hostage after billionaire Steve Getz walks free on a time-served sentence for assaulting his daughters. The episode focuses on the squad's efforts to rescue Rollins and re-arrest Getz, ultimately revealing Judge Ellery and defense attorney Abrams were complicit through bribery and sex trafficking connections. Getz is arrested while attempting to flee the country but is later found dead (suspected murder or suicide). No one is falsely accused in this episode—Frank Bucci kidnaps Rollins (actual crime), Getz is guilty of sex trafficking/rape (not innocent), Judge Ellery is guilty of corruption (not innocent), and Abrams is guilty of facilitating sex crimes (not innocent). The episode deals with a guilty perpetrator evading justice, not innocent people wrongly accused.

Monica Russo, a stripper, reports being raped by celebrity athlete Markeevious Ryan at the Topaz Club. A local precinct officer (Donahue) dismisses her complaint as unfounded after consulting with the club manager (ex-cop Jared), effectively burying the report. Monica then creates billboard art calling out her rapist, leading SVU to investigate. Markeevious Ryan is ultimately arrested, tried, and convicted of rape. No innocent persons were publicly accused or harmed by false accusations in this episode. The perpetrator was correctly identified and convicted.

Former NYPD officer Rachel Wilson commits suicide after making a video statement accusing Gary Wald (her former captain at Vice) of raping her 15 years prior and IAB of covering it up. Her suicide triggers guilt in Sergeant Ralph Morris (who was also at Vice and had an affair with her), leading to his suicide after being questioned by SVU. The investigation reveals Ed Tucker (IAB) had looked into Rachel's complaint in 2004 but was manipulated by his partner Gary Wald into believing it was a fabricated claim. Gary Wald ultimately confesses on tape (via wire worn by Tucker) to 'tuning her up' (assault) when she threatened to expose their affair. Gary is arrested. Tucker, suffering from terminal brain cancer, commits suicide after helping bring down his former partner. The episode contains NO false suspects - Rachel was the victim, Gary Wald was guilty of assault/rape, and all investigative focus was on confirming historical facts rather than wrongly accusing innocents.

Episode centers on boxer Esperanza Morales who punches trainer Romeo Solís after confronting him about sexually abusing 16-year-old Cami Vega. Romeo dies from head injury. Investigation reveals Romeo was NOT abusing Esperanza—her father Santos was the long-term abuser. Esperanza pleads to assault; Santos is arrested for CSA of both daughters. No false suspects meeting the North Star criteria: Romeo was actually guilty of abusing Cami; Santos was actually guilty of abusing his daughters. The case involves actual perpetrators being held accountable, not innocent people being wrongly accused.

Episode centers on Rory O'Toole exploiting immigrant women by demanding sex in exchange for green card approvals. While Duane Varick (subway groper) is arrested and publicly confronted, he is guilty of his offense. His testimony against O'Toole is part of a plea deal. The undercover operation with Rollins/Hasim catches O'Toole before he assaults the UC. No innocent persons are falsely accused or publicly harmed by mistaken accusations in this episode.

Luna Prasada, CEO of We-B-Well, reports being raped by CFO Bobby Frost. Investigation reveals Luna is also accused of embezzlement and sexually assaulting employee Tisa Chee. Luna is arrested, perp-walked, and has breakdown in jail. SVU discovers conspiracy: Bobby, COO Melanie, CTO Vinay, and Tisa fabricated the embezzlement and sexual assault charges to remove Luna from her company. Bobby actually did rape Luna. Tisa's accusation against Luna was completely false, coordinated by conspirators. Luna is publicly humiliated, arrested, and assaulted in jail before being cleared.

Amanda Rollins' sister Kim overdoses and reveals she was sexually extorted by Dr. Paul Capezio, who traded Oxy prescriptions for sex. SVU arrests Capezio and uncovers a broader scheme at Harrington Pharmaceuticals where sales reps use sex to increase prescription volumes. The investigation leads to the arrest of pharmaceutical company president Trey Harrington. No innocent people are falsely accused in this episode; all suspects arrested (Capezio, the sales reps, Harrington) are shown to be guilty of the crimes for which they are accused. Kim Rollins, while initially suspected of prostitution and drug crimes, is actually guilty of those offenses and receives leniency only in exchange for cooperation.

Male dancers Brad, Jason, and Edward secretly recorded sex with female dancers in Studio X and shared videos in group texts. Choreographer Sascha used videos to coerce dancers (Tina, Rose) into sex in exchange for roles. Artistic director Alistair trafficked Ashley to donor after threatening to release her video. Delia's video was posted to porn sites, went viral with facial recognition exposure, causing job loss and career devastation. No falsely accused innocent persons identified—all accused were guilty of various offenses.

Reverend Delman Chase is accused by multiple teenage girls of sexual abuse and grooming. He is arrested, pleads guilty, and is convicted. No innocent persons are falsely accused in this episode. The investigation proceeds correctly from initial credible tip through corroborating testimony to conviction. Chief Garland initially struggles to believe his spiritual mentor could be guilty but ultimately supports the investigation and confronts Chase about his crimes.

Episode focuses on victims of drug-facilitated sexual assault. No false suspects are pursued - Luke Mitchell and Ash Gordon are investigated, arrested, and convicted. All accused parties are guilty. While victims suffered exposure through the dating app press conference, no innocent persons were falsely accused or publicly harmed by wrongful accusations. The case involves designer drugs that evade detection, making prosecution difficult but ultimately successful.

episode_title: The Things We Have to Lose
summary: Episode focuses on the preparation for Sir Toby Moore's sexual assault trial, which is repeatedly delayed. A secondary plot involves Paul Davies being arrested for murder after DNA evidence links him to Dakota Knight's death. A third storyline involves Leon Fuller being shot by Fin after threatening his ex-wife with a knife. Davies is the primary innocent person falsely accused initially (from prior episodes referenced) but is actually guilty in this episode's murder. Leon Fuller appears innocent of the immediate threat Fin perceived but dies before trial. The main false accusation storyline relates to Sir Toby's trial witnesses being harassed.

Jayvon Brown, a Black man working out in Central Park, is publicly arrested after a white woman falsely accuses him of threatening her. He is handcuffed, arrested on outstanding warrants (BLM protest-related), and treated as a suspect in a sexual assault case he had nothing to do with. The arrest is filmed and goes viral. Joe Murphy is later identified as the actual perpetrator but is acquitted by a grand jury skeptical of police credibility after the wrongful arrest. Jayvon loses his job when his NA attendance becomes public, and Captain Benson is investigated by IAB for racial bias.

Will Vargas (14) is wrongly accused of murdering his mother's abusive boyfriend Dwight Wagner. Will falsely confesses to protect his mother Irena, who ultimately admits she killed Dwight in self-defense. Will is charged as an adult before truth emerges. No public exposure beyond legal/family context; harm is primarily legal process and family trauma. Episode also features Fin facing civil lawsuit for prior justified shooting.

Maria Ferraro, Italian exchange student, found dead in freezer. Initially Brad Keegan (her sex partner), Lexi York (roommate who brought home hookup), and Sean Thomas (drug dealer/hookup) were all suspected and publicly exposed. Brad was interrogated and his sexual relationship with Maria exposed. Sean was arrested on suspicion of rape and murder, his name and photo released to media as 'pot-dealer,' accused of 'drug-fueled sexual torture session.' Eventually revealed Perry Moncado (another roommate) accidentally killed Maria by pushing her (she hit head on pipe) then covered it up. Brad and Sean were innocent of the killing; both suffered public exposure and legal consequences for a crime they didn't commit.

Nydia Davis, a 13-year-old foster child, is reported kidnapped on New Year's Eve but is found hemorrhaging at a hospital after being given abortion drugs. She accuses her foster father Ajay Sharma of rape and impregnating her. Evidence supports her claim (Ajay's computer searches for abortion drugs, other foster girls come forward). Ajay is arraigned and remanded, then shot and killed by Nydia's biological father Mickey Davis outside the courthouse. The episode focuses on Mickey's murder trial, where he is ultimately convicted of manslaughter. There is no indication that Ajay was innocent of the sex crimes—evidence consistently supports Nydia's accusations and reveals he had other victims. No qualifying false accusations are present in this episode.

episode_title: Turn Me On, Take Me Private
summary: Zoey Carrera, a cam performer (KendraDream), is sexually assaulted during a live show by subscriber Gabe Miller, who breaks into her apartment. Gabe genuinely believes they are in a romantic relationship and that the assault was consensual roleplay. He stalked her through her father's nursing home (which he recommended), violated his restraining order, and represented himself at trial to cross-examine her. He is eventually convicted of attempted rape after a courtroom breakdown. No innocent persons were falsely accused in this episode—Gabe was the perpetrator from the start. The episode explores the dangers of parasocial relationships in online sex work and the blurred lines perpetrators claim between fantasy and reality.

episode_title: The Long Arm of the Witness
summary: Judge Charles Gallagher dismisses rape case against Ian Hunter, then launches AG campaign claiming 'our sons' are under attack. Investigation reveals Gallagher himself has pattern of raping college women. Ian Hunter is proven innocent via judge's explicit ruling. Investigation into Gallagher reveals multiple victims from college and clerkship; Gallagher eventually convicted.

A serial rapist investigation reveals that Sergeant Ari Moldovan, a decorated 20-year SVU detective, has been committing copycat rapes while investigating serial rape cases. Danny Gonzalez is arrested for multiple rapes but is later revealed to be innocent of at least two attacks. Joey (Black Hood Rapist) was coerced into confessing to two additional rapes he didn't commit to secure prison placement near his sick mother. Moldovan threatened Gonzalez with a weapon and attempted witness tampering. Multiple victims were exposed through police investigation and media attention. Moldovan commits suicide by cop rather than face trial.

episode_title: The Only Way Out is Through
summary: This episode does not contain false accusations leading to wrongful public exposure or harm to innocent people. The main plotlines involve: (1) Jimmy Gunn's parole hearing, where he is actually guilty of multiple rapes and manipulates victims/the system; (2) Xavier Garcia's arrest for sexual assault, where he admits on tape to ignoring withdrawal of consent—he is guilty; (3) Darryl Clark's restorative justice meeting with two sisters he victimized 21 years ago—he is guilty and never denied for the crime he was convicted of (though he initially claims not to remember). No innocent persons are publicly accused or harmed by false allegations in this episode.

A car bomb kills Kathy Stabler, wife of former SVU detective Elliot Stabler. SVU investigates Jacob Peters, a protestor caught firebombing police vehicles, and Sacha Lenski, whose DNA is found on the bomb trigger. Jacob is aggressive but likely not responsible for Kathy's murder. Sacha is arrested but killed in custody before he can cooperate. Neither suspect is proven innocent of the crime they're accused of - Jacob admits to other bombings, and Sacha's guilt/innocence is unresolved due to his death. No qualifying false accusation victims per the rubric.

Ceranda Zajmi, a 17-year-old girl, is murdered. Lonnie Liston, a Black teen on the sex offender registry living in an SRO dubbed the 'pedo motel,' becomes the primary suspect. Detectives question him aggressively, violate his parole, and surveillance him. Community outrage and vigilante violence lead to Lonnie being tortured, mutilated, and murdered by vigilantes who believe he killed Ceranda. Later, DNA evidence proves Lonnie was innocent—the real killer was Sam Johnson, hired by parole officer Roy Eastman to frame Lonnie. Lonnie had a secret alibi (meeting his underage ex-girlfriend) that he couldn't reveal without violating parole. The episode illustrates compounding harms: false public accusation, detective coercion/threats, media/community exposure, and ultimately lynching of an innocent man.

episode_title: Our Words Will Not Be Heard
summary: This episode centers on the kidnapping and intended murder of Sara, a Black documentary filmmaker, by white supremacist group Crew Twenty-Three Two. Sara and her girlfriend Alicia are targeted in a hate crime involving forced sexual acts on camera and a livestreamed auction. The perpetrators (Rick Anderson and Steve, Molly Anderson's brother) are identified and apprehended, with Sara rescued alive. The episode does not contain false accusations of sexual crimes against innocent parties; the criminals are correctly identified and arrested. Background subplot involves Captain Benson learning IAB will clear her in the Jayvon Brown case (a Black man wrongfully detained), but this clearance represents institutional cover-up rather than accountability. No individual is falsely accused of a sex crime in this episode.

episode_title: In the Year We All Fell Down
summary: This episode does not contain a sex crime investigation or false accusation. Restaurant owner Vanessa experiences a mental health crisis during the pandemic and takes a hostage (real estate agent Joey Leonard) before being talked down by Captain Benson. The episode explores pandemic-related stressors including business closure, family estrangement, and loss. No one is falsely accused of a sexual offense. The only 'accusation' context is Vanessa blaming her son Nate for potentially exposing his grandmother to COVID (which led to her death), but this is unrelated to SVU's mandate and there is no public exposure or harm qualifying under the rubric.

Three sex workers (Piper, Despina, Jade) drug and rob wealthy men using a lethal batch of Purple Magic (oxy/fentanyl/MDMA). Xavier Garcia, Paul Landry die; Dr. Linderman survives. SVU discovers Olivia's brother Simon was killed by the same crew a year earlier. The women and their dealer Felix are arrested. No innocent suspects are falsely accused; all arrested parties are involved in the crimes.

Henry Mesner, released from juvenile psychiatric facility at age 18, goes on a killing spree targeting his family and others. He murdered his father, stepmother, and half-brother, then assaulted a college student (Libby Blandon) whose mother had been his psychiatrist years earlier. The episode tracks SVU's pursuit of Henry, culminating in a standoff where Detective Rollins negotiates his surrender. Henry is found competent to stand trial but stabs ADA Carisi in court to feign insanity. This episode contains NO false accusations—Henry is guilty of all crimes. The opening flashback shows Henry's original institutionalization at age 10 for trying to kill his sister and shooting Detective Amaro, establishing his genuine psychopathy. No innocent persons were wrongly accused in this episode.

episode_title: What Can Happen in the Dark
summary: Andy Richards is sexually assaulted by his wife Diana Orsini-Fowler. This is a domestic violence case where the victim (Andy) is male and the perpetrator (Diana) is female. There are no false accusations or wrongly suspected innocent parties in this episode. Andy initially lies about his injuries (claiming workplace accident) to cover for his wife, then Diana falsely accuses Andy of attacking her with a knife (which she actually did to herself). The case focuses on the difficulty male DV victims face in coming forward and being believed. Diana ultimately pleads guilty to misdemeanor sexual assault and assault in the third degree.

SVU investigates a sex trafficking ring where single mothers in subsidized housing are coerced into sexual relationships with government officials and building staff in exchange for apartments. The operation is run by Dr. Catalina Machado of Proud Life nonprofit. No innocent persons are falsely accused in this episode - the investigation correctly identifies the perpetrators of the trafficking scheme. The victims (Rosa Estrada, Denise Campbell, Lulu Davis) are exploited women, not wrongly accused individuals.

SVU investigates Congressman George Justin Howard for sex trafficking and rape of women in subsidized housing. The case involves cooperating witnesses Catalina Machado and Ruben Ortiz. Victims include Rosa, Lulu, Denise, and teenager Jenna Evans. No falsely accused individuals are identified in this transcript - the focus is on prosecuting actual perpetrators. Episode ends with Catalina Machado's apparent suicide by jumping.

episode_title: Never Turn Your Back on Them
summary: Episode focuses on witness protection and murders after Congressman Howard's indictment. Key witnesses Catalina Machado and Ruben Ortiz die (suicides), Paulie Banducci is killed in jail, and Jenna Evans goes into hiding. Detective Kat Tamin is shot during a rescue operation. The episode primarily deals with actual guilty parties (Howard and his lawyer Myron Gold) rather than falsely accused individuals. No innocent persons are publicly accused or harmed by false accusations in this episode - the victims and witnesses are being silenced/threatened, not falsely accused.

episode_title: I Thought You Were on My Side
summary: Tara Reilly, a singer, is raped and pushed down stairs by nightclub owner Gabe Navarro. SVU builds a strong case with DNA evidence linking him to Tara and two other victims (one murdered). However, Navarro is revealed to be under investigation by Organized Crime and FBI for connections to international criminal Anton Popkov. In exchange for cooperation leading to Popkov's arrest, Navarro is placed in witness protection despite being guilty of rape, attempted murder, and murder. No innocent persons were falsely accused in this episode. The case involves a guilty perpetrator escaping justice through federal cooperation, not wrongful accusation of innocents.

episode_title: One More Tale of Two Victims
summary: Two single mothers are raped in front of their children by the same perpetrator who uses a Con Ed/MetroBnB ruse. Ice cream vendor Travis Hillsdale becomes the prime suspect. He is publicly arrested in a park full of children and customers, beaten during arrest, and arraigned. Despite DNA evidence in both cases, the DA withdraws charges related to Crystal Nuñez's rape (preserving only the case involving Deputy Inspector Grogan's daughter Peggy), creating a two-tier justice system. Travis is eventually beaten in police custody before arraignment. While the episode shows Travis is guilty of at least one rape (Peggy's), the handling exposes both victims to public scrutiny and differential treatment based on social status.

TikTok influencer Willa Bartola accuses Tate and Liam Rivers of rape at a content house. The Rivers brothers are tried and acquitted, but later convicted of jury tampering. No false suspects are identified in this episode—Willa's accusation leads to the correct perpetrators being charged (ultimately for jury tampering rather than rape). Diggy Wheeler initially defends the brothers but later testifies against them. He is held in contempt for his outburst but is not falsely accused of a sex crime himself. The episode focuses on the trial and social media dynamics rather than wrongful accusations of innocent parties.

Ian Ridley spent 25 years in prison for murdering/raping Haley West (1996) after confessing under pressure (concussed, traumatized). New DNA testing excludes Ian and identifies tennis coach Roger Murray. Ian was publicly accused, arrested, tried, convicted—entire community believed him guilty. Murray later confesses. Episode also explores Burton Lowe's pattern of sexual misconduct with young women, including Captain Benson when she was 16.

SVU investigates missing sex workers and discovers 14 murdered, mummified victims. Country Jones is initially suspected after being the last person to see victims alive and lying to police. He is arrested, questioned aggressively, shown graphic crime scene photos, and threatened with parole violation. Later timeline evidence proves Country was incarcerated during multiple murders, exonerating him. The actual killer, Trace Lambert, is subsequently identified and confesses.

This episode focuses on Tori Warshofsky, a 17-year-old initially charged with three counts of felony murder for her role in setting up a home invasion robbery that resulted in three deaths. While she admits to texting the victim (Chris) to lure him, she claims she was sex trafficked and coerced by G (David Graham) since age 15. The episode explores whether she was a willing participant or a victim acting under duress. Ultimately, after SVU investigates her trafficking claims and gets corroboration from Jasmine Cruz (another victim), the DA reduces charges to robbery with probation. There are no innocent people wrongly accused in this episode - Tori, Jasmine, and G were all involved in the crimes, though Tori and Jasmine were also victims of trafficking. No one is cleared of wrongdoing after being publicly accused.

Richard Wheatley's trial for the murder of Kathy Stabler. Defense attorney Barba cross-examines multiple witnesses, suggesting NYPD planted evidence and that Elliot Stabler ran a biased investigation. Angela Wheatley testifies she was gaslit by Richard and developed romantic feelings for Stabler. Jacob Peters was earlier arrested for the car bombing but ruled out. The episode focuses on courtroom testimony revealing various investigative methods and relationship dynamics, ending in a mistrial.

A multi-borough hate crime spree targets Jews, Muslims, and Sikhs. Three Black teenagers (Dalen, Jahrique, Julius) are arrested for vandalism/assault at synagogue and street attack. Video of the minors is leaked publicly despite promises of protection. They are actually guilty of their specific crimes. Darko Povic is initially investigated as mastermind but is proven to be a low-level participant coerced by white supremacist network. The real perpetrators are Antonio Juarez (AJ), Tom Nolan, Susan Martell (North Star's wife), and her husband Robert Martell. Episode demonstrates racist assumptions (blaming Black teens) while white supremacists conducted most serious attacks.

No falsely accused innocent persons identified in this episode. Theodore Murtaugh is guilty of kidnapping and assaulting Tino. Carlos Guzmán is guilty of assaulting Murtaugh and separately abusing Andre. The deceased teacher Mr. Delgado abused Carlos as a child. All perpetrators are accurately identified and held accountable. No wrongful accusations or public exposures of innocent parties occur.

Tommy Baker is the victim of an assault/attempted murder by people he knew (Phil Diaz and Ricky Nowak) who then staged it to look like a Grindr hook-up gone wrong. The perpetrators are identified and arrested. There are no falsely accused innocent parties in this episode - Tommy is the victim throughout, and the actual perpetrators (Phil and Ricky) are correctly identified and prosecuted. The Grindr staging was part of the crime, not a genuine investigation path that led to false accusations of others.

episode_title: If I Knew Then What I Know Now
summary: Ashley Peters reports that her birth mother Michelle Young was raped at age 15, leading to Ashley's conception. SVU investigates. Initially Josh Wilcox appears to be the father after Michelle recalls being with him, but DNA excludes him. Cole Eaton is later identified as the actual perpetrator. Josh was falsely suspected but cleared privately through DNA testing before any public exposure or formal consequences occurred. The case resolves with Cole pleading to a misdemeanor.

Radio host Bob Flynn rapes Ellen Kaplan at a charity gala. During the investigation, Flynn boasts to UC detective Rollins about killing his former law partner Kenneth Cross 12 years prior. Detectives investigate the cold case murder and attempt to build cases for both the rape and murder. Flynn is arrested for solicitation of murder-for-hire (targeting Cross's widow Lola when she tries to blackmail him). The episode ends with Ellen's husband Mitch shooting Flynn in the studio after Flynn publicly defames Ellen on his radio show. No innocent people are falsely accused in this episode—Flynn is guilty of rape and appears guilty of the historical murder of Kenneth Cross. Lola Cross was involved in blackmail schemes with her late husband but is a victim of Flynn's violence, not falsely accused.

Episode centers on prosecution of three Bishop Club members who raped freshman Annabel Nelson. Initial denials of 'it was consensual' are typical perpetrator defense, not evidence of false accusation. All three ultimately face consequences (Jacob gets deal for testimony, Brad/Austin plead guilty). No innocent persons are accused or harmed by false allegations in this episode. The conspiracy charges against other club members are dropped as part of negotiation to close the club, but transcript does not show anyone proven/implied innocent after being publicly accused.

episode_title: Sorry If It Got Weird for You
summary: Jackson Wright, CEO of dating app Mr. Wright Now, is accused of raping employee Lisa Rose after they matched on his app. He is later convicted at trial. There are no false suspects or wrongfully accused individuals in this episode. Detective Velasco briefly appears as a potential suspect when Lisa has a traumatic reaction on their date, but she immediately clarifies he did nothing wrong and no accusation is made against him. The case focuses on Lisa's credible rape accusation against Wright, which is substantiated by testimony from CFO Cress Gordon (who reveals Wright also raped her years earlier) and Wright's own courtroom outburst. Wright is found guilty.

episode_title: Once Upon a Time in El Barrio
summary: SVU investigates the trafficking of young girls from Juarez to New York. One victim (Maribel) is murdered; others are rescued. A corrupt NYPD captain (Kubiak) is discovered to be exploiting the victims. No innocent persons are falsely accused in this episode—the traffickers Jorge and Lourdes Padilla are guilty, and Captain Kubiak is guilty of sexual exploitation of minors. The episode focuses on trafficking victims and corrupt police rather than wrongful accusations.

Dustin Tinsley is wrongfully arrested for raping Kayla in Central Park after her wallet is found in his bedroom. He is publicly arrested, charged with rape, DV, drug/gun possession, held at Rikers, then released when DNA evidence links the rape to serial rapist Aaron Wesley Parker. Dustin's sister Demmy planted the wallet to frame him for Kayla's rape, hoping to escape her brother's decade-long sexual abuse. Dustin is later re-arrested for raping Demmy. Episode demonstrates false accusation with major public exposure (press conference, news coverage, arrest) followed by exoneration, then revelation of actual guilt for different crimes.

Two parallel narratives: In 2001, 13-year-old Aretha Green disappeared the day before 9/11; her body is found in 2022 in Central Park. Investigation reveals her grandfather Coleman killed her after impregnating her. In present day, rape victim Libby Blandon is arrested for grand larceny after Major Case Detective Szabo illegally accessed her rape kit DNA from OCME database. SVU discovers Szabo used this tactic on at least 6 victims. DA eventually drops charges against Libby and announces legislation to ban the practice. Multiple suspects cleared in both cases before true perpetrators identified.

Nick Pearce (using alias Luke Davis) groomed and kidnapped 14-year-old Beth Lee after infiltrating her church and family for 2.5 years. He manipulated both parents (conducting an affair with the mother, sexually assaulting the father) to gain access to Beth. He is the actual perpetrator throughout—no false suspects or wrongly accused persons appear in this episode. Beth was found at a remote cabin, then attempted to marry Pearce. A pregnancy test confirmed Pearce as the father, leading to rape charges. No innocent persons were publicly accused or harmed by false allegations.

episode_title: Confess Your Sins to Be Free
summary: Audrey O'Neill is raped after leaving her door unlocked for her lover. Investigation reveals that a priest, Father John Regis, used confessional information to identify and rape married Catholic women having affairs. Father Ryan Duffy, who took confessions from Regis about the crimes, is initially arrested for attempted rape in a UC sting but is eventually cleared when the actual perpetrator (Regis) is caught confessing at his mother's grave. Additionally, Burton Lowe (a recurring character) accepts a plea deal for sexual misconduct against Beverly Morrison after attempting to make amends in his recovery program.

episode_title: A Final Call at Forlini's Bar
summary: Episode focuses on Delia Hackman, a long-term domestic violence victim who kills her abusive husband Ty Hackman after years of beatings and sexual assaults. She is arrested for murder but ultimately receives a favorable plea deal after medical evidence reveals severe CTE from repeated head trauma. No false accusations or innocent suspects appear in this episode—the case is straightforward: Delia killed Ty, and the legal question is whether it was justified self-defense or murder. The episode also explores Olivia's relationship tensions with both Barba (who defends Delia) and Stabler.

John Ken, a hotel employee, is blackmailed by Sirenko into providing security access after being set up with an underage girl who claimed to be 18. He is publicly confronted/arrested by police at his residence in Queens when they storm the house hunting for Sirenko. He is later cleared as a victim of blackmail/exploitation, not a willing participant in the bomb plot. The exposure to law enforcement and the nature of the confrontation constitute public harm, though we don't see consequences beyond the immediate arrest scene.

A tourist family from Ohio is attacked on a NYC subway by four gang members. The father is killed with a machete, and the 14-year-old daughter Nora is raped. All four perpetrators are identified through witness statements, DNA evidence, and video footage. Two suspects (Matisse and Sleep) die during apprehension - one shot during arrest, one falls from a roof during pursuit. The remaining two suspects (Ricky and Sabo) plead guilty to rape charges. No innocent persons are falsely accused or publicly exposed in this episode. The investigation focuses on the actual perpetrators throughout.

Pop star Austin Boyer is accused of raping his girlfriend, singer Kelsey Jones. Initial assault complaint in a limo is dropped when Boyer proposes. After a second incident following a restaurant fight, Kelsey reports rape. Austin claims rough consensual sex. Trial proceeds despite emotional complexity and social media harassment of Kelsey. Jury convicts on rape third degree; Austin sentenced to sex registry. No false suspects or wrongfully accused innocent persons identified in this episode.

Episode centers on home invasion/kidnapping of Priya Singh (15) by Elias Olsen, who was attempting to please his father Soren. Investigation reveals Soren and Elias held two women (Gillian Moore, Nadine Chavez) captive for over a decade in basement. Soren is found dead (shot in back of head); both captive women confess to protect unknown shooter. Priya is rescued unharmed. No false accusations or wrongful public exposure occur in this episode. All suspects arrested are actually guilty of crimes (Elias for kidnapping/shooting Singhs). The women were victims throughout, never wrongfully accused.

Diego Rodriguez accuses his boss Paul Greco of rape. Before trial, Diego drowns under suspicious circumstances. Investigation reveals Greco sexually assaulted multiple lifeguards and falsified qualification scores in exchange for sex or money, leading to ten drownings. No innocent persons are falsely accused in this episode. Greco is the perpetrator throughout.

Maggie D'Angelo is sexually assaulted at a secret party after being drugged with scopolamine. Her boss Spencer Lewis is initially suspected and publicly questioned at his workplace in front of his business associate (Lena Hess). Spencer provides DNA samples and is cleared when the DNA doesn't match. The actual perpetrator is identified as Ethan Schmidt, a timpanist who confesses. Lena Hess is revealed to be running a blackmail operation, filming powerful men at sex parties. Spencer is ultimately cleared of the assault but faces exposure of his sexual activities captured on hidden cameras.

Paulo Rocha, a famous soccer player, is accused of sexual assault by reporter Nellie. Investigation reveals 12 prior civil suits and a pattern of sexual misconduct. Antonio Campos (Paulo's business manager) discovers Paulo raped his 16-year-old daughter Ana. No false suspects identified - Paulo is guilty of the crimes he's accused of throughout the episode. Antonio shoots at Paulo after learning the truth but doesn't harm him. Paulo pleads guilty to rape three.

Aida McDaniels, a trans woman, is murdered by Lukas Peeters, who also attacks another trans woman, Cora Jones. The actual perpetrator is identified and convicted. Aida's father, Detective Mark McDaniels, tampers with the crime scene by removing evidence of his daughter's gender identity out of shame. No innocent persons are falsely accused or publicly exposed in this episode. The main investigative focus is on the guilty party (Lukas Peeters), and while Detective McDaniels' crime scene tampering delayed justice, no third party was wrongly accused or suffered public exposure as a result.

This episode focuses on the trial of Elias Olsen (a defendant accused of kidnapping and rape). While Detective Muncy's testimony becomes contentious due to her calling him names and admitting she threw a radio at his head during arrest, Olsen himself is NOT shown to be innocent. The case ends in a mistrial due to a hung jury, with plans to retry. The transcript contains NO persons who are accused then proven/strongly implied innocent. The Elias Olsen case involves a defendant whose guilt is supported by victim testimony (Priya Singh identified him, Mrs. Singh made voice ID). His defense attorney attempts to discredit the arrest and investigation tactics, but this is standard defense work, not evidence of innocence. The secondary plotline involves Ray Sprague and Troy (motel employees) who are arrested for hidden cameras - they are actually guilty. No false accusation scenarios are present in this episode.

Captain Benson goes to the Bronx to help clear cases during a DOJ investigation. Detective Bruno reveals that Pup Peters was wrongfully convicted for a series of rapes of deaf schoolgirls 10 years ago. A new murder of a deaf girl (Renee Perry) proves Peters was innocent—the real rapist (Ronnie Samuels) is caught via DNA. Peters' confession was coerced: he was in withdrawal and signed a document in exchange for drugs. The episode shows systemic failure to listen to deaf victims and wrongful imprisonment, but Peters' exposure was limited to the interrogation room and court proceedings—no public workplace/family/media exposure is shown beyond the standard criminal justice process.

Episode focuses on gang recruitment through rape and Captain Benson's pursuit of Oscar Papa. No innocent suspects are publicly accused or exposed. The perpetrators (Bug Bear, Sacrilege, Benny Barros/maestro, Oscar Papa) are all guilty. Albert Diaz (Fugazi) is a victim/child soldier coerced into attempting murder, not falsely accused of rape. Maria Garcia is a rape victim who cooperates then sets up Benson, but is never accused herself.

This episode focuses on the prosecution of Oscar Papa, leader of the BX9 gang, for multiple rapes and attempted murder of Captain Benson and her son Noah. A parallel plot involves Fin and Bruno discovering a serial rapist veterinarian who drugs and assaults sex workers. No false accusations or wrongful suspicions of innocent people are depicted in this episode. All suspects pursued (Oscar Papa, the BX9 recruiters, Dr. Tim Birch the veterinarian) are shown to be guilty of their accused crimes.

A serial rapist stages car accidents using a hacked traffic device to target women, while posing as an EMT. George Kalazakis, a used car salesman, is wrongfully accused based on a mistaken ID by the victim's fiancé. Police interrogate him and his wife discovers he was having an affair. Though cleared by DNA, he suffers public exposure and marital consequences from the investigation. The actual perpetrator is Clark Young, whose crimes were motivated by his wife's infidelity.

Ivan 'Dutch' Hernandez confronts Fin 23 years after Fin arrested him for drug possession. Dutch reveals he was raped in the Tombs holding cell after the arrest, and spent 23 years in prison being repeatedly assaulted. The episode follows Fin helping Dutch identify and arrest his rapist (Virgil Hatton) and the corrupt CO (Pete Ryan) who facilitated it. No false accusations are made in this episode - the focus is on historical prison rape. Dutch was actually guilty of the drug charge he was arrested for, though he was railroaded through the system. Virgil Hatton and Pete Ryan are arrested for the rape that occurred 23 years ago. The only 'wrongful' element is that Dutch's original arrest led to systemic abuse, but he was factually guilty of drug possession.

Neurologist Pence Humphreys, suffering from dementia, confesses to raping and murdering his wife Winnie. SVU discovers CPAP machine data proves he was asleep during the murder. His caregiver's nephew Kevin Wise actually committed the crime. Pence initially falsely IDs Kevin in lineup then attempts suicide when confronted with his innocence. Parallel storyline: Velasco interrogated about confession to 2003 Fort Worth double murder; reveals teenage involvement with cartel sicario training but claims he did not pull trigger (friend 'Chilly' did). No public exposure of either false suspect—Pence's confession kept within legal system, Velasco's interrogation internal only.

Zoe Green reports being raped by 'Klaus Darcy,' a man she met online. DNA evidence initially points to Cooper Davis, the 23-year-old nephew of Zoe's deceased husband, who is a sperm donor. Cooper is questioned by detectives but has an alibi and is cleared. The actual perpetrator is revealed to be Jenna Scott, Zoe's best friend, who created the Klaus persona and used Cooper's donated sperm to attempt to impregnate Zoe without consent. Jenna is arrested and tried; she's acquitted of aggravated sexual abuse but convicted of sexual abuse in the third degree (misdemeanor).

SVU investigates a drug-facilitated gang rape at a divorce party. An undercover operation exposes a family-run operation (Patesh family) that drugged women at bars and delivered them to hotel rooms for paying clients. Officer Churlish goes undercover as bait and is nearly victimized herself. The case involves bartender Arlo and ultimately leads to arrests of Sunil, Asha, and Rav Patesh, plus cooperation from multiple bartenders/bouncers. Two Canadian men who assaulted the original victim (Abby) are apprehended by Interpol. No wrongfully accused individuals are identified in this episode—all suspects investigated are confirmed involved or complicit.

Martin Parish rapes interior designer Mona Stewart, who initially reports but then recants after being paid off by Martin's mother Connie. Mona is later murdered via slow poisoning (industrial abrasive mixed into cocaine). Investigation reveals Martin's mother Connie has been controlling and abusing Martin through poisoning and incestuous behavior. Martin is guilty of rape; no false suspects identified. Peter Parish (Martin's father) was previously poisoned by Connie but left the family. This episode contains no false accusations leading to public harm - Martin is guilty, and the father's victimization occurred off-screen years prior.

Episode involves legitimate guilty parties in a sex trafficking case. Roger Briggs is accused of involvement with underage prostitution at an exclusive club and possessing child pornography. Evidence (photos in his locker) supports charges. He dies choking before trial. His wife Lorraine Maxwell (head of Trial Division) is present when he dies; circumstances are suspicious but ruled accidental. No innocent persons are publicly accused or harmed by false accusations in this episode. The Velasco/Chili subplot involves tracking a legitimate fugitive cartel hitman.

After debate team member Naomi Hayes sets her team's bus on fire, she initially accuses her male teammates of rape before disclosing that her coaches (a married couple) assaulted her. The coaches claim the relationships were consensual. A former student, Colin Sharpe, testifies as a character witness for the coaches but breaks down on the stand, revealing he was also groomed and assaulted years earlier. Both coaches eventually plead guilty. The male teammates were initially suspected and questioned but proven innocent.

Episode involves two distinct case tracks: (1) A series of stranger rapes where perps knew victims' names and took selfies, ultimately revealed as revenge-for-hire scheme; (2) Murder investigation of Mark Reed found tortured in a cage, leading to arrest of Elias Olsen. Multiple men are initially suspected in the rape cases (Billy Vitale, Greg, Derek, Harvey Bergman) but are cleared when it's discovered they hired others to commit the assaults. Elias Olsen is proven guilty of Mark Reed's murder, not a false accusation case. The rape-for-hire perpetrators (Junior Suarez and accomplices) are the actual guilty parties, while the men who hired them face potential solicitation charges.

Episode focuses on SVU's investigation of the Shadowerk website (a dark web platform for hiring crimes) alongside a serial rapist case. Randy Gordon commits multiple sexual assaults (Kate Wallace, Manny Lopez, Yves Nettey) unrelated to the website. All suspects arrested (Gil Hughes, Randy Gordon, Jacob Bettencourt) are guilty of their accused crimes. No innocent persons are falsely accused or publicly exposed. The Shadowerk defendants (Billy Vitale, Junior Suarez, Harvey, Gil Hughes) are arraigned for crimes they actually solicited/committed. Kate Wallace is a victim throughout, not an accused person. No qualifying innocent persons for person_rows.

15-year-old Maddie Flynn is abducted from a store. During the investigation, SVU pursues multiple suspects who are later cleared: Gordon Franks (photographer who took pictures of girls' soccer team), Sam (owner of anatomically-correct doll resembling Maddie), and Hal (another doll owner who paid for the kidnapping but tried to cancel). All three men face public exposure and consequences despite being innocent of the actual kidnapping. The real kidnapper is identified as 'George from Canada,' who drugged and trafficked Maddie. Episode ends with Maddie still missing but another victim, Tanya Garcia, recovered.

During a smash-and-grab robbery at a boutique, Natalie Ross is sexually assaulted in a dressing room by Jay Watson, an 18-year-old participant in the looting. The case involves DNA evidence from a bathing suit liner, and Natalie initially struggles to identify her attacker due to concerns about systemic racial injustice in the criminal justice system (her foster brother Yves had a traumatic juvenile arrest experience). She ultimately identifies Jay Watson in court, and he pleads guilty. The episode contains no qualifying false suspects - all investigated individuals were either actually guilty (Jay Watson) or involved in the robbery but not the rape. Travis Butler, who participated in the robbery, was accurately suspected of robbery and cooperated by identifying Jay Watson as the rapist. No one was proven or strongly implied innocent of accusations that caused public harm.

Episode focuses on Dr. Ray Goldberg who is drugged and sexually assaulted by two men (Duvall and Reese) who force an escort (Tess) at gunpoint to have sex with him. The case involves identifying the perpetrators rather than clearing false suspects. Dr. Goldberg initially denies remembering the assault to protect his marriage but eventually cooperates in a controlled meet to get confessions. Both perpetrators take plea deals. No innocent persons are falsely accused or publicly exposed in this episode.

Episode involves the search for and rescue of Maddie Flynn, a 15-year-old kidnapping and trafficking victim. George Ross Brouchard (the kidnapper/trafficker) and Leonard Fleming (the buyer) are arrested. No innocent persons are falsely accused or publicly exposed in this episode. The case involves actual perpetrators who are guilty of the crimes they're accused of.

Shea McGrath, daughter of Chief Tommy McGrath, reports being sexually assaulted at a party. She initially falsely accuses her math tutor Saagar (18), leading to his arrest and public confrontation by the chief. Saagar is later cleared via alibi and DNA. The actual perpetrator is revealed to be Liam Dowling (15), a family friend. The case involves significant professional complications due to the chief's personal involvement, his threats toward the innocent suspect, and domestic violence in the Dowling household.

Two college men (Hayden Foote and Frederick Hwang) are initially suspected of raping tourist Leah Tan. Investigation reveals they participated in a competitive 'game' targeting foreign women but did not rape Leah. The actual rapist was their friend Dustin Renfrow. Both Hayden and Frederick faced public interrogation, school expulsion proceedings, and reputational harm before being cleared of the rape (though expelled for the game itself). Hayden separately confessed to raping a different victim (Nikol) on New Year's Eve.

Episode centers on serial killer Tori Brock who murdered her sexually abusive father and two child predators. Wayne Miller was found dismembered; investigation revealed child porn on his computer and photos of girl (Nora Boyd) in his vintage car. Miller and second victim Gary Turner were lured via K-Dome app by Tori posing as her younger sister Nina. Both men were already dead when SVU began investigating. No innocent persons were wrongfully accused publicly or suffered consequences from false accusations. The 'suspects' (Miller, Turner, James Brock) were either already dead or actually guilty of the crimes attributed to them.

Two Colombian men (Javier Lopez and Mateo Garcia) are attacked in a hate crime by three men from New Jersey who assume they are gay. The attackers (Zach Swann, Mo Franks, Jordan Ramirez) are arrested and identified by witness Anne Holmes. All three attackers are prosecuted; there are no wrongfully accused persons in this episode. The victims are the targets of violence, not false accusation. No innocent person is accused of the sexual assault or hate crime.

Four teenage boys carry out a wolf pack sexual assault in Fort Tryon Park, attacking Rosie Meadows (who later dies) and kidnapping Sydney Lynch. Seth Piper, son of an exterminator, is identified as the ringleader. All four perpetrators are arrested after a standoff at a townhouse. DNA evidence links them to multiple unsolved rapes on Long Island. No innocent persons are wrongly accused in this episode - the investigation correctly identifies the actual perpetrators from the beginning through DNA evidence, witness testimony, and surveillance footage.

Episode centers on the trial of George Brouchard for kidnapping and sexually abusing 15-year-old Maddie Flynn. A mistrial occurs when a juror claims she was coerced but also reveals romantic feelings for Brouchard. The trial proceeds with Brouchard representing himself.
